urn:contentItem:7V12-SSH0-YBDY-R03C-00000-00North in for bad fire season2009-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6North in for bad fire seasonKathleen Skene

THE North's summer drenching could make for a savage bushfire season later this year -- but not everyone agrees on how best to prepare.

Rural Fire Service acting area director Tony Woods said abundant rain now meant more fire-fuelling vegetation for the dry season.

``Obviously the current weather and the amount of rain that's around, once it dries out, will enhance the fuel loadings,'' he said.

``The grass will be longer. . . and the trees might increase their leaf foliage.

``There will be some significant impacts.''

The Environmental Protection Agency, along with Townsville City Council and the Rural Fire Service, use controlled burns to prepare the region for the dry season -- a strategy that environmentalists have labelled cruel and ineffective.

The federal environment department confirmed this week it had received a nomination to include controlled burning on the list of 17 `key threatening processes', along with introduced rats, cane toads, greenhouse gases and other environmental nasties.

A threat has not been added to the list since March 2006.

A spokesman for Environment Minister Peter Garrett yesterday would not comment on `hypothetical' additions to the register.

``Anyone can make a nomination under the EPBC (Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation) Act, but it has to go through rigorous scientific evaluation processes,'' he said.

``Our position is that the protection of life and property is paramount.''

Cardwell resident Ian McCallan organised a petition in 2007 urging the Queensland Government to stop burning in the region's parks, saying that the smoke was a health hazard and the fire safety benefits were unproven.

This week he said many locals believed controlled burns were cruel to animals and that adding them to the threatening processes list was `a good idea'.

``Anything that can't outrun the fire gets burnt alive and that is trivialised by QPWS,'' he said.

``The Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service are responsible for about 10 million tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions.

``They call them hazard reduction burns, but they've never actually been tested.''

Mr McCallan said burning the vegetation degraded the topsoil of forests, causing erosion and run-off to the reef.

``The forest starts to become very sparse, very dry -- up here, if you keep destroying it, you're actually creating a forest fire threat that wasn't there before,'' he said.

``They do it just prior to the wet season -- it's crazy, absolutely crazy.''

A statement issued by the EPA said the department had done more than 800 planned burns covering about 1.3 million hectares.

The EPA said protecting life and property was a higher priority than wildlife conservation.

``Queensland's parks and forests are allocated into zones for fire management purposes,'' the statement said.

``Prescribed burning programs are prepared for these zones after considering a number of key factors including protection of life and property, zoning priorities, vegetation communities, fuel loads, climate conditions and the history of previous fires in the area.''

The statement said controlled burns were a `vital ingredient' in the maintenance of plant and animal diversity.

Mr Wood said all rural fire service-controlled burns were carefully planned and managed.

``If controlled burns were banned or restricted, you could see an escalation in wildfires and the intensity of fires would be a lot greater because of the unburnt fuel,'' he said.

``The potential for injury to volunteers and the community as well as property and the environment is going to cop an impact.''

urn:contentItem:5HSW-8F01-JD67-12VP-00000-00Tasmanian firefighters head to Victoria as death toll climbs2009-02-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisAGRIBUSINESSTasmanian firefighters head to Victoria as death toll climbsLUKE SCOTT

A contingent of more than 90 Tasmanian firefighters has left the State this morning to battle the deadly blazes in Victoria.

More than 20 bushfires in Victoria are still out of control, and the Tasmanian contingent has been told to expect ``tough, tall timber fire fighting in steep terrain''.

The Tasmanian contingent, drawn from the Tasmania Fire Service, Parks and Wildlife, and Forestry Tasmania, left the State as news broke that the death toll from the fires had reached 108.

TFS acting deputy regional chief Stephen Lowe briefed firefighters from the North and North-West at the Launceston Airport this morning and told them conditions would be difficult.

Their expertise in difficult terrain would prove invaluable, Mr Lowe said.

``We expect to be involved in hard, manual control line construction, using bulldozers, as well as firefighting in gullies and steep terrain -- tall timber type fire fighting,'' Mr Lowe said.

``The working environment will be steep and there will be a lot of hard work in the gullies.''

He warned the firefighters to stay hydrated, and to be aware that community members had been severely impacted by the fires.

``The last thing I need to say is look out for each other, stay safe,'' he said.

After delivering the briefing, Mr Lowe said sending such contingents away to other states allowed the TFS to gain first-hand knowledge of fire events as well as assist to bring fires under control.

``This is a good example of inter-agency cooperation,'' he said.

``We've sent contingents to NSW twice before, and this is the third contingent we've sent to Victoria.

``It is good for firefighting across Australia.

``These type of fire events are very rare -- we experienced the same sort of event, though not to the same scale, with the fire that went into Scamander.

``But for our guys to go over there, and get some experience in tall timber forest fire fighting -- it doesn't come very often and it is very valuable.

The TFS contingent is expected to return to the State on Friday, and Mr Lowe said a decision would then be made on whether more firefighters would be deployed.

Two of those firefighters leaving Launceston yesterday were Devonport's Stuart Bennell and Marc Herbert.

Mr Bennell has been with the TFS for nine years.

In 2001, he was sent as part of a TFS contingent to NSW to battle fires around Sydney.

Mr Bennell said he was proud to be part of the Tasmanian team set to help out in Victoria.

``But it will be hard work,'' Mr Bennell added.

``A lot of hard work.''

Fellow firefighter Mr Herbert has been with the TFS for more than two years.

The trip will be his first interstate as part of a firefighting contingent.

``I'm expecting it to be difficult work in difficult terrain,'' Mr Herbert said.

``But we are happy to be able to help.''

Tasmania Police has also offered its support to Victoria, and a three-man disaster victim identification team was expected to leave Hobart for Victoria this morning.

Tasmania Police previously sent three crime scene examiners to Thailand in the wake of the Boxing Day tsunami in 2004, where they worked to help identify victims of the disaster.

A two-man Tasmania Police disaster victim identification team was also sent to Indonesia in 2002 after the Bali bombings

urn:contentItem:5HSW-8F01-JD67-12XR-00000-00Get ready to flee, more fires coming2009-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisAGRIBUSINESSGet ready to flee, more fires comingPAUL AUSTIN

Victoria's bushfire emergency is not over, with today and Friday looming as extremely dangerous.

People in the Warburton Valley and Yarra Valley could come under direct threat today.

Fire chiefs are warning residents of these areas that if they plan to leave rather than stay and try to defend their properties, they should leave early today.

CFA state duty officer Neil Bumpstead said residents would be most at risk after the wind change forecast for late this afternoon.

Mr Bumpstead warned that if fire did reach the Warburton Valley, people who had left should be prepared to stay away for several days.

"We cannot stress enough that with limited road access in the Warburton Valley, traffic may become congested," he said.

"Being on the roads is dangerous during a fire threat."

The Enoch Point area, near Gaffneys Creek and south of Eildon, was of particular concern, with winds expected to turn north and north-westerly today at speeds of between 20km/h and 30km/h.

State duty officer at the Department of Sustainability and Environment Andrew Graystone said today's forecast was also for extreme forest fire danger in the Mallee and very high forest and grassland fire danger across the state, with the exception of East Gippsland.

The CFA has declared today a day of total fire ban in the north-western, north-eastern, eastern and central districts.

Premier John Brumby urged people in fire-prone parts of the state to implement their fire survival plans.

Mr Brumby said no Victorian should need to be reminded that the state is very dry after a drought lasting many years and then the baking heat of recent weeks.

"It doesn't need much to make them (fires) run," he said.

"So for people in those threatened areas, put your fire survival plan in place ' and if you're going to stay and defend, do all the things that are in the rule book."

Concerned about a rift between the CFA and the firefighters' union about how the fire services performed on Black Saturday, Mr Brumby called for an end to finger pointing.

He said Victorians should work hard to avoid a repeat of what happened after the Ash Wednesday fires of 1983, when many firefighters resigned from the CFA "because lives were lost and they thought they hadn't done enough, that they'd failed".

"That's the last thing we want in Victoria now," Mr Brumby said on 3AW before yesterday's Day of National Mourning service.

"I don't know of any firefighter who didn't do their best.

"I've met some who led hundreds of people down the mountain (at Kinglake) and saved lives.

"I've met so many who've lost their own home ' their own home ' while they were out trying to save someone else's.

"So the most important thing in the next few weeks is, we don't want to be in the recrimination business, saying that firefighters could have done better, or this or that.

"They did their best, and the emergency services people did their best."

Mr Brumby said the bushfires royal commission would investigate all issues, including the performance of the CFA and other emergency services and the adequacy of fuel-reduction burning policies and emergency warning systems.

"We'll let the royal commission work out what went wrong, what went right and what we need to do in the future to fix things up," he said.

urn:contentItem:7V06-K1C1-2RG7-2126-00000-00Communities pull together as bushfires continue to rage2009-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisCommunities pull together as bushfires continue to rage

Authorities in Victoria are warning communities to be vigilant as the deadly bushfires continue to burn across the state.

Several blazes are threatening homes across Victoria, and despite a cool change wind continues to hamper efforts to bring the fires under control.

The death toll has continued to rise, with the latest confirmed total sitting at 156.

The highest toll was recorded at Kinglake, north of Melbourne, were 35 people died, including former Channel 9 Melbourne newsreader Brian Naylor.

In the destroyed town of Marysville, the recovery team co-ordinator Howard Paix said the community has united in the face of the disaster.

"It is a tough time, but you see community come together," he said.

"You see people work out what is real and what is the essential things in life and how relationships are so important. And seeing a whole community pull together is just marvellous."

Kinglake resident Jessica Barnes was overcome by the community reaction, she told ABC1's Lateline program.

"I don't know what to say and it makes me cry every time I see people and see what everyone's done. And everyone, everyone is doing something. And it's wonderful," she said.

The Army, police and CFA volunteers spent yesterday searching burnt out houses and cars for more victims of the fires.

Brigadier Michael Arnold, who is heading up the Australian Defence Force Joint Taskforce, says his team was ready to be called up.

"We started our planning for this around about November last year," he said.

"We had earmarked units for this that have been involved in other bushfire type situations in the past, there's a lot of corporate knowledge in the reserve here in Victoria when it comes to firefighting, and we've tapped into that straight away."

Remain vigilant

Fires across the state have destroyed more than 740 homes, and are still threatening property in some areas.

Residents of Healesville north-east of Melbourne are warned they could be directly affected by ember attack, with winds in the region picking up throughout the night.

The water supply in the area has also been affected by the fire, but at present is secure.

Nina Cullen from the Department of Sustainability and Environment says residents need to be prepared.

"The Toolangi area, there's a fire that continues to burn south-east in a northerly direction, and residents are advised impacted directly by fire," she said.

"Similarly in the Healesville area, residents in the vicinity of Dowd road, Romeo Road, Anderson Road, Gibbs Road and Juliet Avenue will be directly impacted upon by heavy ember attack."

The Churchill fire, east of Melbourne, is no longer posing a direct threat to communities around Won Wron, but residents are urged to stay vigilant.

The Blaze at Dederang, near Beechworth in Victoria's north-east, escalated during the day and is spotting ahead of the main fire.

Residents in the area need to act on their fire plans.

The Yea-Murrindindi forest fire is about 93,000 hectares in size, and while it is not posing a threat, residents are reminded to be vigilant.

Fire activity at Kinglake has settled down for now.

urn:contentItem:7V13-FJ10-Y9Y8-S0B1-00000-00Bushfires still burning, one week on2009-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisBushfires still burning, one week on

One week after Victoria's deadly bushfires began, firefighters are still battling 12 blazes burning across the state.

Favourable weather conditions this weekend are expected to assist fire crews batting the bushfires, which have claimed at least 181 lives, destroyed more than 1,800 homes and scorched 450,000 hectares of land to the north, north-east and east of Melbourne.

The blazes have also left about 7,000 people homeless and the death toll is expected to rise.Lives lost in Victorian bushfires: 181Victorian Bushfire Hotline: 1800 240 667Red Cross - missing persons: 1800 727 077Country Fire Authority updatesMore ABC coverage

Of the fires still burning across Victoria, none are threatening property.

The main concern is around Alexandra and Healesville, north-east of Melbourne, where crews are working on containment lines.

The CFA says the Kinglake complex of fires is still causing concern and 60 bulldozers are building fire breaks in high-risk areas, including Healesville.

The Department of Sustainability and Environment's Mark Woodman says fire crews are also paying special attention to the Yea-Murrindindi fire to the north-east of Melbourne.

"There's been some active fire generally in the Healesville [area] but it's burning up areas like Mt Juliet. It's not threatening any assets."

Interstate and international firefighters are also arriving to give local crews a break.

Arson

Meanwhile, a man who cannot be named has been charged over the Churchill-Jeeralang bushfire in eastern Victoria.

The man has been charged with one count of arson causing death, one count of deliberately lighting a bushfire, and one count of possessing child pornography.

Victoria Police Assistant Commissioner Steve Fontana is urging the public to be on the lookout for arsonists.

"If you do see suspicious activity, please call 000," he said.

"If you see people acting [like] you don't think they belong in the area, that they're potential arsonists or thieves, please call us on 000."

Melbourne smoke cloud

Melburnians are being warned the smoke haze covering the city will stay for much of the weekend.

The city has been shrouded in haze since yesterday, as south-easterly winds pushed smoke towards the city.

Ambulance Victoria's Paul Holman is warning everyone to stay inside today if possible.

"Particularly those with asthma, respiratory conditions, the elderly and the young [should] stay indoors today," he said.

"Have your medication available [and] if you don't have to go outside and exercise, don't do it today."

Peter Blake from the weather bureau says the smoke will hang around for Sunday.

"Certainly smoke haze [will hang] around and temperatures [are] getting up to about 28 degrees," he said.

"But apart from the smoke, it could cause a bit of problems seeing the sun at times too."

Mr Blake predicts there will be no decent rain.

"Unfortunately there's no rainfall expected over any bushfire areas," he said.

"The only shower activity we're expecting over the weekend is in east gippsland, and that's only some isolated showers around."

US support

Meanwhile, the US Secretary of State, Hillary Clinton, has offered her sympathy to the bushfire victims.

"President Obama and Prime Minister Rudd have discussed the situation by phone and we have sent forest fire specialists to help the Australians out," she said.

"We want our Australian friends to know that we mourn with them over the loss of innocent lives in this tragedy."

27</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Bushfires subsided and some roads<br/>reopened across the ACT today as temperatures dropped and winds<br/>eased after four days of horrific conditions.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">All fires were contained and one was put out after almost 200<br/>firefighters from the ACT, 40 from NSW and 40 other officers from<br/>Victoria joined forces.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">There were no injuries.<br/></p><p>A total fireban which was imposed on Christmas Eve was cancelled<br/>in the ACT, but a ban remained in force for the southern tablelands<br/>area, including Queanbeyan.<br/></p><p>Smoke which filtered across Canberra was diminishing as the main<br/>Stromlo pine forest fire west of the city was generally contained.<br/></p><p>The Red Hill fire just two kilometres from Parliament House and<br/>the Oaks Estate blaze near Queanbeyan were both contained at the<br/>perimeters.<br/></p><p>Fire crews on the ground and a water bombing team in the air<br/>took advantage of cooler weather conditions and weaker winds and<br/>contained fires by 11:30am (AEDT).<br/></p><p>A total of 1,500 hectares of land with a 54 kilometre perimeter<br/>was burned during the last four days, with some fences and sheds on<br/>rural properties damaged.<br/></p><p>The main thoroughfares of Tuggeranong Parkway and Cotter Road<br/>were reopened to traffic, but the Red Hill summit road, Uriarra<br/>Road West from Coppins Crossing in the west and Lady Denman Drive<br/>from Black Mountain to the National Aquarium remained closed.<br/></p><p>The Emergency Services Bureau warned drivers to take care on the<br/>road with smoke still obscuring vision and wildlife on or near the<br/>roads after fleeing the fires.<br/></p><p>Nature reserves remain closed and some power was still out in<br/>the Red Hill area.<br/></p><p>Emergency Services Minister Ted Quinlan today urged people not<br/>to try to gain access to nature parks, bushland and forest areas,<br/>which would remain closed until next week.<br/></p><p>He said people had been patient and thanked fire and emergency<br/>crews for sacrificing Christmas celebrations with their families to<br/>fight the blazes.<br/></p><p>"These people abandoned Christmas dinners and family<br/>celebrations to protect our city and for that, I thank them," Mr<br/>Quinlan said.<br/></p><p>The temperature gauge reached 23 degrees Celsius in Canberra<br/>today but tomorrow was expected to be dry with light winds and a<br/>temperature of 26 degrees.<br/></p><p>Conditions would be hot and dry and windy on the weekend with<br/>tops of 32 degrees expected, the weather bureau urn:contentItem:4P7G-YNP0-TXN5-R379-00000-00REGULAR SHORTS1989-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 10REGULAR SHORTS

STAR WARS LOSS

WASHINGTON, Wednesday: The US House of Representatives voted yesterday to slash "Star Wars" anti-missile research despite arguments that the cut would delay a decision on deploying the space system until the next century. The House voted 248-175 to cut President Bush's $US4.9billion ($A6.5billion)request to $US3.1billion. Mr Bush said cuts would seriously damage promising tests to determine if the United States could rely more on a nuclear defence and less on offensive nuclear missiles. - Reuter

MONSOON DISASTER

NEW DELHI, Wednesday: The Indian army and navy have launched wide-ranging rescue missions in western Maharashtra State's coastal areas, where thousands have been marooned in lashing monsoonal rains and floods that have already killed 750 people. Ships have been sent out in search of more than 2,000 fishermen lost in the Arabian Sea and Indian Ocean. - AFP.

B-17 CRASHES

LONDON, Wednesday: A World War II B-17 bomber crashed in flames during the making of a film yesterday, but a Royal Air Force spokesman said all 10 people aboard survived. The US-built Flying Fortress was taking off from a disused air base in Binbrook, eastern England, when it hit a tree, crashed through a fence and came to rest in a cornfield. - REUTER

FOREST FIRE CHAOS

WINNIPEG, Wednesday: Forest fires burning out of control in Canada have forced more people from their homes in Ontario, while in Manitoba, about 19,000 have been evacuated to safer surroundings. The fires have consumed more than 1.5 million hectares in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Ontario. Smoke drifted as far as Labrador. - AP

urn:contentItem:4P89-SFM0-TXN5-V20T-00000-00Indonesia fears fire disaster1999-08-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 13Indonesia fears fire disaster

JAKARTA.- Indonesian President BJ Habibie, warning of an environmental disaster, called for action to stop forest fires in Sumatra and Borneo from spreading.

"I just want to remind you of the need for us to be ready in facing the forest fire disaster," Mr Habibie said at the opening of an environmental workshop yesterday.

The fires raised concerns in neighbouring Singapore and Malaysia of a repeat of the thick smog which blanketed the region after similar burn-offs two years ago.

Environmental experts have accused Mr Habibie's government of doing little to tackle the blazes and of being preoccupied with his bid for a second term as president.

PNG defence chief accused

PORT MORESBY.- Suspended chief of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force, Major General Jerry Singirok, has been referred to the Public Prosecutor's Office for possible criminal prosecution.

Gen Singirok becomes the first serving head of the PNG Defence Force to be referred to the Public Prosecutor under the country's Leadership Code.

A British supplier to the PNG Defence Force is alleged to have paid Gen Singirok K67,950 (about $A39,300) among other alleged offences.

The Ombudsman Commission, PNG's corruption watchdog, said Gen Singirok was being investigated for alleged breaches of the Constitution.

Public prosecutor Panuel Mogish was now considering whether there was enough evidence to refer the commander to a Leadership Tribunal for prosecution.

Fight over West Bank timing

JERUSALEM.- The chief Palestinian negotiator insisted yesterday that Israel resume a West Bank troop withdrawal in September, while Israeli officials said the pullback could only begin in October after Palestinians fulfilled their peace obligations.

Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak has asked US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright to postpone a visit until the dispute over the implementation of the Wye River land-for-security agreement has been settled. Mr Barak said withdrawal would start in 30 days, but Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat said implementation of the Wye Accord was overdue and should have been completed by February, 1999.

urn:contentItem:49N9-VX80-01S8-D2FR-00000-00<published>1992-03-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Deaths threaten UN peace moves: IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BELGRADE - At least 11 people died and dozens were wounded today in new fighting in Croatia and Bosnia-Hercegovina.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The violence - which caused one of the highest one-day death tolls since a UN-sponsored truce took effect on January 3 - threatened to delay full deployment of 14,000 UN peace-keepers.</p><p>The clashes across central and eastern Croatia suggested frustrated fighters on both sides were jockeying for position before the peacekeepers arrived.</p><p> Destroyed NEW YORK - A team of UN chemical weapons experts left Iraq today after destroying hundreds of war-damaged, leaking rockets and shells, and finding many more buried under rubble and debris, officials said.</p><p> City strafed ISTANBUL - At least one Turkish jet strafed the city of Sirnak today, said residents as the death toll in fighting in southeast Turkey between Kurdish separatists and police edged toward 100.</p><p> Palace shots KABUL - Loud explosions were heard late today in Kabul near the palace of Afghanistan's president, after which intense small fire arms broke out, witnesses said.</p><p> Cousteau plan PARIS - Explorer Jacques-Yves Cousteau today unveiled plans to broadcast a daily bulletin to the world on the earth's health.</p><p>India torture LONDON - Amnesty International said today hundreds of people in India, including pregnant women and children, had died in recent years from beatings and torture while in custody.</p><p> Fire blast MOSCOW - A forest fire caused a huge blast at a Pacific Fleet ammunition depot near the Russian Far Eastern port of Vladivostok.</p><p> And finally . . .</p><p>VATICAN CITY - Workers restoring Michelangelo's Last Judgement in the Sistine Chapel will leave intact most of the 40 or so modesty garments painted over its nude figures by subsequent generations. An official said today it was "for technical and historical reasons and not because of any moral judgement".</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WRAP - ACT bushfires ease for the first time in four days</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>By Linda McSweeny </nameText></person></author></nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>CANBERRA, Dec 27</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Bushfires subsided and some roads<br/>reopened across the ACT today as temperatures dropped and winds<br/>eased after four days of horrific conditions.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">All fires were contained and one was put out after almost 200<br/>firefighters from the ACT, 40 from New South Wales and another 40<br/>officers from Victoria joined forces.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">There were no injuries.<br/></p><p>A total fireban which was imposed on Christmas eve was also<br/>dropped in the ACT, but a ban remained in the southern tablelands<br/>area, including Queanbeyan.<br/></p><p>Smoke which filtered across Canberra was diminishing as the main<br/>Stromlo pine forest fire west of the city was generally contained.<br/></p><p>The Red Hill fire just two kilometres from Parliament House, and<br/>the Oaks Estate blaze near Queanbeyan, were both contained at the<br/>perimeters.<br/></p><p>Fire crews on the ground and a water bombing team in the air<br/>took advantage of cooler weather conditions and weaker winds and<br/>contained fires by 1130 AEDT.<br/></p><p>A total of 1,500 hectares of land with a 54 kilometre perimeter<br/>was burned in the four days of flames, with some fences and sheds<br/>on rural properties damaged.<br/></p><p>The main thoroughfares of Tuggeranong Parkway and Cotter Road<br/>were reopened to traffic, but the Red Hill summit road, Uriarra<br/>Road West from Coppins Crossing in the west and Lady Denman Drive<br/>from Black Mountain to the National Aquarium remained closed.<br/></p><p>The Emergency Services Bureau warned drivers to take care on the<br/>road with smoke still obscuring vision and wildlife on or near the<br/>roads after fleeing the fires.<br/></p><p>Nature reserves remain closed and some power was still out in<br/>the Red Hill area.<br/></p><p>Emergency Services Minister Ted Quinlan today urged people not<br/>to try to gain access to nature parks, bushland and forest areas,<br/>which would remain closed until next week.<br/></p><p>He said people had been patient and thanked fire and emergency<br/>crews for sacrificing Christmas celebrations with their families to<br/>fight the blazes.<br/></p><p>"These people abandoned Christmas dinners and family<br/>celebrations t protect our city and for that, I thank them," Mr<br/>Quinlan said.<br/></p><p>The temperature gauge reached 23 degrees Celsius in Canberra<br/>today but tomorrow was expected to be dry with light winds and a<br/>temperature of 26 degrees.<br/></p><p>Conditions would be hot and dry and windy on the weekend, with<br/>tops of 32 degrees expected, the weather bureau said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4GNC-H2Y0-015G-P14M-00000-00<published>2005-07-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 9</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Doom & Gloom</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CLIMBERS DIE IN MOUNTAIN PLUNGE</p><p nitf:lede="true">THREE mountain climbers fell 400m to their death in the French region of Montblanc today.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The two men and a woman, all French nationals from the Alpine Club in Le Mans, were descending when they lost their footing at 3700m.</p><p nitf:lede="true">And three people died on Saturday climbing Ukraine's highest summit in a group event whose participants included Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>About 16,000 people accompanied Yushchenko on the annual ascent up Hoverla Mountain, about 2000m above sea level in western Ukraine's Carpathian Mountains.</p><p>TOURIST PLANE CRASHES INTO SEA</p><p>SIX people, whom authorities believe were US tourists, were killed when their small plane crashed into the sea off Costa Rica's Pacific coast.</p><p>The accident happened on Saturday just off the coast of Flamingo beach, north-west of capital San Jose.</p><p>And a Russian-made plane believed to be carrying more than 50 passengers and crew has crashed deep in a forest in Equatorial Guinea, killing all aboard and leaving bodies scattered about the crash site.</p><p>FIREFIGHTERS PERISH IN FOREST</p><p>AT LEAST 11 firefighters have died in a forest fire raging out of control along a 17km front in central Spain.</p><p>A government spokesman said as many as 14 people may have died, trapped by the blaze that has scorched thousands of hectares in the Guadalajara area, east of Madrid.</p><p>SQUEEZE IS PUT ON INSURGENTS</p><p>US, AFGHAN and Pakistani forces have killed more than 60 suspected foreign militants and Taliban insurgents during the past three days in a series of clashes in restive tribal lands in Pakistan's North-West Frontier Province and neighbouring Afghan regions.</p><p>The fighting follows a warning by a senior US official last week that forces on both sides of the border needed to "squeeze" the region where al-Qaida leader Osama bin Laden might be hiding.</p><p>TIGERS THREATEN RETURN TO WAR</p><p>TAMIL Tiger rebels warned today of an imminent return to Sri Lanka's two-decade civil war, vowing to carry arms in government-held areas  a move that could rupture a three-year ceasefire.</p><p>Rebels would take counter-measures if the military followed through on a vow to stop them, the head of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam's political wing said.</p><p>SECURITY FORCES ATTACK REBELS</p><p>TURKISH security forces hunting members of an autonomy-seeking Kurdish rebel group killed 10 rebels and confiscated explosives and weapons in south-eastern Turkey, local officials said today.</p><p>The four-day operation in a triangle of the south-east cities of Van, Sirnak and Hakkari began on Wednesday.</p><p>The rebels were killed when they opened fire on security forces.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:53RK-KFV1-F0JP-W4H1-00000-00Forests fan the flames of prosperity2011-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisTALKING POINTPg. 26Forests fan the flames of prosperityMartin Moroni

Proper forest management is vital for Tasmania's environment and economy

FORESTS are dynamic systems, constantly evolving and changing.

We must not think that a forest reserved will remain as it was when reserved, that old forests will remain old. We must accept that forests change and that many forests will benefit from management.

Tasmanian forests have a close relationship with fire. Our tall and iconic forests require severe fire for their birth and in the absence of fire cannot effectively reproduce.

Generally, wherever you see wet eucalypt forests in Tasmania, wildfire has occurred, and will return once again.

We have not had very large landscape-level fires since 1934. Even the 1967 fires, which burned the outskirts of Hobart, were probably only medium-sized.

The dead standing trees seen on the foothills of Mt Wellington are largely from the 1967 fire, indicating the damaging extent of these fires.

The 1934 fire was estimated to burn five to six times the areas of the 1967 fires, and larger fires are thought to have pre-dated the 1934 fire.

In my lifetime, and in the lifetime of many Tasmanians, we have not seen a Tasmanian mega-fire or even a medium-sized forest fire.

However, the low levels of fire in the past 50-80 years have allowed the forests to age and accumulate the woody biomass that is the fuel for wildfire. It is just a matter of time until the next large landscape wildfire occurs. We may find ourselves in a similar position to Victoria, where 3.5 million hectares have burned since 2003.

To lock away forests and pretend they will all grow old and never burn is a common misconception in Tasmania, and a dangerous one. We may be stoking the next catastrophic wildfire.

Under extreme weather conditions, forest management cannot prevent wildfire and we can do little to stop severe forest fires, other than protect infrastructure and lives.

In this system, with infrastructure and residences adjacent to and in forests, we may want to provide access points to fight fires and manage fire fuel loads around important places, to limit the intensity and severity of wildfire and give us a chance to prevent fires from burning our infrastructure and homes.

If forest management is greatly reduced, the infrastructure and experience associated with, and funded from, forest management will likely diminish. Access to our forests will decrease as roads are closed and removed. Expertise that has taken many decades to develop will fade away and we will lose the ability to manage our forests for all their values.

If the flow of wood from forests is substantially reduced, with it will go the income stream that people rely on. It is likely that many of our great rural communities will struggle, shrink and even disappear.

There will be many flow-on effects. As the forest industry withdraws there will no longer be a need for those to service and supply equipment. As these businesses and foresters withdraw, so will their patronage of local shops, doctors, schools, markets and businesses, and many may no longer be viable.

Furthermore, we will lose the firefighting capacity of the industry, both in terms of trained firefighters, but also the infrastructure needed to fight fires, such as roads and bridges, that may allow us to protect our infrastructure and human lives in the next wildfire.

More than half of the people employed in the Tasmanian timber industry depend on native forest management, and in 2009-10 the estimated final value of wood products from logs sourced from native Tasmanian state forests was $563 million.

Large reductions in the Tasmanian native forest industry will not only hurt our rural communities, but the whole state economy. Every Tasmanian will feel the effects of losing hundreds of millions of dollars from the state's revenue streams.

* Martin Moroni is Forestry Tasmania's senior research scientist, forest carbon. He also worked for the Canadian Forest Service as a climate change scientist working on the forest carbon cycle.

urn:contentItem:4B4P-GK40-015G-V20X-00000-00<published>2003-12-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FIRE AWARENESS SUPPLEMENT; Pg. N12</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Troops ready, willing and able</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Last season's terrifying bushfires have hardened the resolve of firefighters on the front line</p><p nitf:lede="true">BEN Rankin was hailed as a home-town hero after Swifts Creek survived one of the most ferocious days of this year's devastating alpine fires.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> He won't easily forget January 30, when a huge joint effort by firefighters from the Department of Sustainability and Environment, Parks Victoria and the CFA battled some of the worst conditions he had encountered.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "It was the toughest day of my 30-year fire fighting career," Mr Rankin said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> For a further two weeks, the town was threatened by fire in the north, west and east.</p><p>A small army of firefighters, who struggled to hold containment lines and extinguish numerous spot fires, doubled the town's population of 450.</p><p> Their efforts saved the town's main assets, although a couple of houses in surrounding communities, together with fencing and grazing, were lost.</p><p> As incident controller of the Swifts Creek incident management team, Mr Rankin led the firefighting team through an exhausting 58-day campaign.</p><p> "There was pretty much a constant threat to assets, which made it a fairly demanding experience," said Mr Rankin, who is a level three controller and DSE fire management officer for Swifts Creek and Bairnsdale.</p><p>  "The role of an incident controller is to co-ordinate the event to ensure that the people in the incident management team, right down to the fire line, have the opportunity to do the best job they can," he said.</p><p>Jessica does</p><p> the hard yards</p><p>GIPPSLAND chemical engineering student Jessica Hunt will put her studies aside this summer to join the Department of Sustainability and Environment's seasonal crew of project firefighters.</p><p> Ms Hunt, from Briagolong, is one of more than 700 project firefighters who will support DSE's permanent, specialised firefighters this season.</p><p> Ms Hunt is already an experienced campaigner, having fought the 60-day Bogong fire in Gippsland earlier this year.</p><p> She has also been involved with her local CFA since she was 11 and became an operational firefighter at 16.</p><p> "Both my brothers had been on crews before and it was something I wanted to do too," Ms Hunt said.</p><p> "I worked right through the Bogong fire with various crews, including the CFA.</p><p> "I was in Omeo on Australia Day, when a backburn got away from us, which was a bit scary, but everyone was fine."</p><p> Ms Hunt's contribution was acknowledged by firefighting colleagues, who said she had done a fantastic job under pressure.</p><p> "She really showed the worth of the summer crews," said DSE catchment management officer Les Kewming, who worked alongside her.</p><p> Hard training</p><p> pays off</p><p>FIGHTING a bushfire on unfa miliar terrain was one of the many hurdles Longwood CFA volunteer Max Cox faced during January's high country bushfires.</p><p> Coming from the flat grasslands of Euroa, Mr Cox relied on his training to battle fires on steep hills and unfamiliar tracks.</p><p> "The area was very inhospitable and different," Max said.</p><p> "On the flat, the wind blows from one direction but in the hills it creates funnels that light up the gullies.</p><p> "Training really came to the fore."</p><p> Mr Cox, an excavator from Longwood, has been a CFA volunteer for more than 40 years and is the group officer at Euroa.</p><p> In January, he spent eight days fighting fires at Dartmouth, Stanley and Corryong.</p><p> Mr Cox, who led a team of 12 CFA volunteers, said January's bushfires were the worst he had seen and hoped the experience gained by younger CFA volunteers would prove valuable in the future.</p><p> "It was great experience for our young blokes to see how awesome it was," he said.</p><p> "In my time I've never seen anything like it. The commitment of the volunteers left nothing to be desired."</p><p>Gary takes on</p><p>a new role</p><p>GARY White, of Ballarat, is one of DSE's five new regional fire prevention officers appointed in response to the Victorian bushfire inquiry.</p><p> Mr White, who brings 25 years of forestry and forest fire management experience to the role, will co-ordinate fuel reduction burning and ensure a consistent approach across Victoria.</p><p> "Fuel reduction burning will not prevent forest fires but it will reduce the fuel load on the ground making suppression actions easier," Mr White said.</p><p> "While the weather can cause the postponement of planned fuel reduction burns, my role will help ensure opportunities are maximised and targets are met where possible."</p><p> Mr White's most recent fire role in the south-west was as an aviation specialist, which involved supervising fire bombing and managing the Aircraft Unit at major fires.</p><p> He has also worked in production forestry, silviculture extension and has considerable experience of forest fire prevention and suppression.</p><p> "I will be liaising closely with other fire prevention officers across the state, which means we can develop a consistent, statewide approach," Mr White said.</p><p> "Coming from a practical and management background I want to strengthen the link between field operations and fire management."</p><p>Fourth time</p><p>for Sasha</p><p> THE 2003-2004 fire season will mark Sasha Masierowski's fourth year as a DSE project firefighter.</p><p> Last summer, Ms Masierowski was based in Mildura but was kept busy with the Big Desert fire in December and several other fires in the Mallee.</p><p> She also spent many weeks fighting fires in the north-east.</p><p> "I first heard about project firefighters when I did natural resource management after VCE and it sounded like a good summer job," Ms Masierowski said.</p><p> "Working in the north-east was a great eye-opener.</p><p> "You never understand the powerful force of fire until you see something like that.</p><p> "My safety and the crew's safety is the most important issue.</p><p> "You can replace equipment but you can't replace people."</p><p> Like many people working on the fires last season, Ms Masierowski gained a huge amount of experience as well as many new friends.</p><p> "I've made some of my closest friends through doing this job," she said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:459X-KGB0-0197-B0W2-00000-00<published>1996-01-31T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 16</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>RADIANT HEAT A BIG KILLER IN BUSHFIRES</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">RADIANT heat is a major killer in wildfires. People are rarely killed by the flames - radiant heat, asphyxiation and dehydration are responsible for almost all deaths.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Colin Squires, a CFA communications officer at Truganina Brigade, between Melton and Werribee, said radiant heat caused enormous injuries to unprepared people.</p><p>"Many people have no idea on how radiation can affect them," he said. "Radiation can go through the glass windows of a house and set up fires inside before the flames get there. "</p><p> He said the same thing could happen to people inside a car.</p><p> Getting ready to fight radiation burns was essential if living in a likely bushfire area, Colin said. He said sheltering under blankets stopped radiation burns.</p><p> According to Joan Webster, who wrote The Complete Australian Bushfire Book, the radiant heat of a bushfire can burn the leaves of trees 40m away.</p><p> She writes that a person in shorts and t-shirt or a summer dress with much bare skin exposed who tries to flee from or suppress a bushfire, will die within 15 minutes.</p><p> The key to survival is to protect yourself from radiant heat in the 10 or so minutes it takes the fire front to pass.</p><p> There are two basic ways to protect yourself.</p><p> Getting out well before the fire front reaches your area or seeking shelter in a well prepared home are the only ways your survival can be assured.</p><p> Some people panic moments before a fire reaches their home and try to drive from the fire. But cars provide much less protection from radiant heat than buildings do.</p><p> Though a car may provide sufficient protection from grass fires, which emit less radiant heat over a shorter period, in many circumstances they will not protect you from a forest fire.</p><p> Last-minute evacuations caused the most deaths in the Ash Wednesday bushfires of 1983 with 26 people killed in or near cars, or close to houses.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:5B9Y-F4T1-JCBD-B272-00000-00Homes ruined, forests a moonscape as fire rages2014-01-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisAPg. A001Homes ruined, forests a moonscape as fire ragesAlex McConachie

Homes ruined, forests a moonscape as fire rages INTO THE FURNACE: A fire truck heads towards a huge fire that caused an emergency warning to be issued after a wind change put homes at risk in villages near Wagga Wagga. Photo: LES SMITH By Alex McConachie Continued Page 4 At least three homes have been destroyed and more remain under threat as a large bushfire continues to rage out of control at Carabost, south-east of Wagga.

A fire in the Copperhannia National Park, near Bathurst, is also out of control.

The Carabost fire, burning in dense pine plantations in and around the Murraguldrie State Forest, had burnt more than 8000 hectares by Sunday night and remained at a watch-and-act alert level.

Flames in the plantations crowned at more than 2 times the size of the trees, reaching at least 100metres in height as they ripped their way through the forest.

What were once thriving pine plantations just two days ago had been reduced to barren and lifeless moonscapes by the fire, which was believed to have been started by a lightning strike on Saturday afternoon.

Variable winds in the area had been causing difficulty for firefighters, who were trying to establish containment lines ahead of an anticipated wind change on Sunday night.

Firefighters were working to establish a major break to the southern and western sides of the fire before a wind change from the north-east, forecast to arrive about midnight, swung the fire around once again.

Riverina Rural Fire Service community safety officer James Smith said firefighters were "as confident as we can be" that their containment lines would hold in the face of the blustery conditions.

"The lines at this stage are as strong as we can make them," he said. "When the conditions are right we work to make those lines even deeper."

More than 900 firefighters battled 93 fires across NSW on the weekend and 200 of them have been tackling the Carabost blaze, aided by two Homes destroyed, forests a moonscape as blaze rages FIRE'S RAMPAGE: The Murraguldrie State Forest fire, as seen from Carabost Road, and the eerie remains of the forest after the fire had swept through, as seen from Tumbarumba Road. Photos: LES SMITH From Page 1 Skycrane helicopters and a number of fixed-wing aircraft.

Thick smoke from the fire blanketed much of the region, and ash fell across large sections of the fire ground for most of the day.

Emergency warnings were twice issued for the blaze, one about 1am on Sunday and another at 3pm as the blaze rampaged through pine forests on Tumbarumba and Carabost roads.

The second emergency warning was triggered after a strong south- westerly change swept through the fire ground shortly beforehand, whipping the fire into a frenzy as it began to intensify in speed and strength.

Residents in the Carabost area were ordered to evacuate after the second warning and were being told to stay away on Sunday night by the RFS, as the fire continued to threaten homes in the area.

The flare-up threatened to cross Carabost Road to the east, where it would have ignited another large pine plantation and potentially placed Humula under threat, but quick work by firefighters ensured the inferno was held at bay.

When the blaze ignited late on Saturday afternoon, firefighters were initially concerned for the township of Humula, home for about 200 people.

Fanned by gusty south-westerly winds, it quickly rampaged north- east through the Murraguldrie State Forest before a wind change turned the danger away from the town and towards properties in the vicinity of Carabost.

Despite the danger appearing to have passed on Sunday, the town remained eerily silent as the inferno continued to menace to the south.

urn:contentItem:49N0-D1M0-01S8-G2B3-00000-00<published>1991-10-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>SERBIA GRABS POWER AS TALKS CONTINUE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>AAPINTNEWS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Serbia grabs power as talks continue BELGRADE: The leaders of Serbia and Croatia prepared to attend peace talks yesterday despite fierce fighting and a Serbian move to grab the remnants of federal power. Serbia moved to consolidate its control over what remains of Yugoslavia, announcing that it was taking over the near defunct federal Parliament.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>A senior Western diplomat said the move effectively dissolved the eight-member federal presidency, which nominally controls the Serb-dominated Yugoslav army. The Serbian decision was condemned by Macedonia, which like Croatia and Slovenia has declared its independence, and Bosnia-Hercegovina, where Croats and Muslims live in growing tensions with Serbs. The army, which launched a major assault against Croatia this week, bombarded areas around historic Dubrovnik, starting a raging forest fire, and closed in on the Croatian capital of Zagreb. Croatian leaders say the attacks on the Adriatic, in the eastern Croatian region of Slavonia and in Banija, south of Zagreb, represent a bid by Serbia to define a ""Greater Serbia" which would include most of Yugoslavia. Federal presidency representatives from Montenegro, Serbia, and Serbia's two provinces decided to take over the federal Parliament at a meeting which included the Defence Minister and army commanders. Croatian President Franjo Tudjman and Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic were reported to be heading to The Hague yesterday, where peace talks sponsored by the European Community continued. Zagreb television reported that Croatian forces had been pushed back to within 12km of the republic's capital, after losing several villages to federal fighters. Yugoslav navy warships closed off Dubrovnik, an international tourist attraction which has been without water, power or telephones for three days. Gen Andrija Raseta, deputy commander of the federal military district, which covers much of Croatia, said yesterday Croatian forces must surrender or leave Dubrovnik.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:53HN-2TY1-F031-X3GF-00000-00Riots behave like bushfires, says expert2011-08-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisRiots behave like bushfires, says expertMarianne English

Despite their unpredictability, riots show certain patterns and phases similar to a bushfire, researchers say.

And, they add, understanding the psychology and motivation of riot participants can help cities prevent peaceful protesting from escalating to violent or destructive rioting.

The events surrounding the police's part in a British man's death catalysed riots that quickly spread in England this week. Although race tensions seem to influence the rioting, unemployment, cuts to public programs and a stale economy have factored in, too.

But how do riots' destructive and violent grasps on an area spread?

Dr Kristian Skrede Gleditsch, a professor of government at the University of Essex in the United Kingdom, says the geography of riots and how they spread seem to show certain patterns - patterns similar to those followed by wildfires.

"There's some evidence suggesting that ... the severity of riots is inversely proportional to their frequency," he says. "It's kind of like a forest fire. Most fires go out very quickly, but a few become catastrophic. Once they reach a certain magnitude, they can become self-sustaining and very hard to contain."

In the case of the England riots, Gleditsch says the situation has moved past the point where police can contain violence from spreading to new locations. He says it will be interesting to study what allows urban riots to grow to this magnitude, whether they're shaped by police strategies or other factors.

Shedding identity and responsibility

Dr Jack Levin, a professor of sociology and criminology at Northeastern University in Boston, says most rioting consists of two phases in which people's motivation to behave violently or destructively may change.

Dropping one's personal identity and responsibility and adopting those of a group's (a behaviour known as deindividuation) often happens in the first phase of rioting, he says. Usually, people are pushed to their personal limits before expressing their grievances this way.

Following the initial catalyst, and with rioting spreading, people's rationales for participating in change, too.

"It has to be recognised that economic times are pretty harsh, not only in the United States but in England. There are desperate individuals who will unfortunately go outside of the law simply because they've lost confidence in mainstream politics, see the police as the enemy of occupation, and don't see the light at the end of the economic tunnel," says Levin. "They may take advantage of a dire situation in order to accumulate certain items - such as flat screen TVs - that they otherwise might not."

According to Levin, these free-for-all bouts of looting transition into a second phase of rioting and often happen when newcomers join with individuals they already know. For example, friends showing up at a riot are probably pressured by one another to act destructively rather than acting to support the original grievance.

Though outsiders should try to understand the rationale of riot participants, Levin says riots can range from the "sublime to the ridiculous," adding that it's become trendy to riot over less serious events such as the victory or loss of a sports team.

Lowering standards

Another researcher points out the difference between violent and destructive behaviours, adding that riots are more likely to lower people's standards for themselves, regardless if they have a criminal history. Overall, vandalism and looting, which are technically property crimes, are easier for people to justify than behaving violently.

"I think the threshold to engage in their choice of [destructive] behaviours is lower," says Dr Sherry Hamby, a research associate professor of psychology at the University of the South in Sewanee, Tennessee. "The main thing to understand about this group psychology is that individual psychology probably explains a small percentage of these behaviours."

Though police reports and media sources might focus on the extremes of a riot and accuse all participants of having a criminal history, the truth is existing criminals are unlikely behind this riot's genesis and progression, she says.

"The criminal element doesn't really change from week to week or month to month - they're always out there," says Hamby. "You can't usually pinpoint something like that. It's not the criminals that are getting the riots really going; they're more political events than they are criminal events."

urn:contentItem:496G-CV00-015G-P3YD-00000-00<published>2003-08-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES-COLUMN- EDITOR; Pg. T07</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Fanning the cows while Rome is burning</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Natasha Bita</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Et cetera</p><p nitf:lede="true">ELECTRIC fans help Tuscan cows keep their cool. Even the cicadas feel too hot for summer serenading. Italy's gone troppo. The longest, hottest summer in living memory has turned the Mediterranean's climate tropical. Temperatures 7C above average since early June have warmed Italy's Tirreno Sea (bound by the islands of Sicily, Sardenia and Corsica) to 27C -- the highest on record and up with the Caribbean.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>The heatwave is having disparate effects: flooding in parts of Europe and elsewhere crop failures, blackouts and bushfires caused by prolonged drought. "France is thirsty," bellowed Le Figaro newspaper, as the French Government imposed water restrictions on households and farmers. Italy's Government ordered water from the Alps be diverted to replenish the Po, which environmentalists claim has not been so dry since the reign of Julius Caesar. As temperatures hit the high 30s, La Repubblica declared it the hottest summer since 1782. The Corriere della Sera claimed it was too hot even for the cicadas to sing. "Many cicadas have thrown in the towel," it reported, quoting experts from Florence's Institute of Biometeorology. "Mute. Because singing, as you know, is tiring."</p><p> Across Europe, water shortages paralysed inland shipping this week as rivers became too shallow for cargo boats. The Danube had to be dredged deeper to clear a traffic jam of barges, while only lightly-laden boats could navigate Germany's Rhine. Farmers demanded a financial bail-out from the EU, claiming crop losses of 5 billion euros. Tuscan farmers, worried the heat would dry up milk production, took to installing fans to keep their cows cool. But in a development to cheer Australia's free-trade lobby, the drought prompted some commentators to question the wisdom of subsidising low-value crops that require excessive irrigation. "Italy consumes 30 billion cubic metres of water to cultivate crops of which a good half is useless," hydrologist Giuliano Cannata was quoted in L'Espresso.</p><p> Precious water was also in demand for aerial firefighting. Portugal appealed to Spain for help to control a vast forest fire in its north, while France sought Italy's assistance to extinguish fires along the French Riviera that killed five tourists. But as the south went up in flames, storms lashed northern Italy this week. Australia is not the only land of drought and flooding rains.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49P8-51X0-01S8-G1Y9-00000-00<published>1995-08-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>RESIDENTS GO HOME AS FIRE DOUSED</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT Residents go home as fire doused NEW YORK: Evacuees were allowed back home yesterday as exhausted firefighters cleaned up a wind-driven forest fire that had threatened high-priced Eastport beach resort communities in New York State. Authorities said the 2400ha blaze looked like arson, and critics asked why promised federal airplanes to bomb the fire with water did not arrive until yesterday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Bulldozers were used to create a dirt ring around the perimeter of the 8km by 2.5km fire zone. Nonetheless, officials baulked at declaring the fire contained because of the slight chance that it could flare up again without warning in the midst of million-dollar real estate. The area has not had rain in 19 days. About 40 firefighters had an assortment of minor injuries. However, the blaze, feeding on tinder-dry pines and oaks 110km east of New York City, destroyed one home and a timber yard, damaged seven other homes and a train station, and shut down railways and roads. Soon after noon yesterday, 400 evacuated Westhampton residents went home. Some spent two nights sleeping in high school gyms or their cars. Joseph Monteith, Suffolk County Police chief, said arson was suspected in the blaze that started on Thursday. Two other fires were reported that night along Long Island's south shore, and a police task force was investigating if they were linked to the larger blaze. The fire won't be officially declared under control for at least three or four days. The area will be surveyed with an airborne infrared detector to ensure that every hot spot and ember is extinguished. Associated Press REST at last . . . firefighters in Suffolk County, New York State, take a breather after fighting forest fires which raged through their area since Thursday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC OF FIREMEN TAKING A BREATHER AFTER FIGHTING A FIRE FOR 3 urn:contentItem:44DX-HCT0-015H-9315-00000-00<published>2001-07-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 15</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Man's burnt hand will be tucked in his abdomen</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DARRELL GILES</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">DOCTORS will perform revolutionary surgery on a firefighter by tucking his burnt left hand inside his abdomen for three weeks in a bid to heal the skin.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Jason Emhoff survived a deadly forest fire, north-east of Seattle, Washington, this month, but received burns over 25 per cent of his body.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Four young firefighters were killed and six others seriously injured in the massive blaze in the Cascade Mountains on July 10.</p><p>Emhoff's father, Steve, said his son was leading a crew of five firefighters who suddenly found themselves trapped by flames in a valley.</p><p> As the fire raced towards them, the five ran downhill towards the Chewuch River and finally crawled inside their emergency fire shelters as the flames overran them.</p><p> "He was the only one who made it out," Steve Emhoff said of his 21-year-old son.</p><p> Doctors yesterday grafted Emhoff's own skin on to his right hand, which is his dominant hand. But it was unclear how functional the hand would be.</p><p> But his left hand was damaged so badly -- blood vessels were destroyed down to the tendons -- that doctors will try the unusual procedure involving the abdomen.</p><p> "We're going to make a little pocket in the abdomen and bury (the left hand) with skin on top of his fingers, so in three week's time the blood supply will grow into his hands," said Dr David Heimbach, director of the burns unit at Seattle's Harbourview Medical Centre.</p><p> Then doctors can graft skin on top of the new blood vessels, he said.</p><p> "Otherwise it won't take. It would be like trying to graft skin on to a tabletop," Dr Heimbach said.</p><p> The procedure, known as a Crane flap, has been done once before at Harbourview. Without it, Emhoff would have a less functional left hand, perhaps with fingers placed in a set position.</p><p> Surgeons have removed burnt areas on both of his thighs, his right calf, right arm and forearm, and spots on his back.</p><p> Dr Heimbach said they nearly ran out of healthy skin for grafting and turned to an artificial product made of collagen that heals like normal skin.</p><p> Emhoff was expected to remain in hospital for up to six weeks.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4TGB-15N0-TX5N-01BP-00000-00Financial fire to last two years, says analyst - GLOBAL FINANCIAL CRISIS2008-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisFINANCEPg. 22Financial fire to last two years, says analyst - GLOBAL FINANCIAL CRISISTeresa Ooi

Trading

``A FINANCIAL forest fire is sweeping through the market, burning the deadwood and it will take sometime before the forest is regenerated.''

So declared Wilson HTM Investment Group institutional stock adviser Simon Robinson yesterday as stockbroker dealing rooms were swamped with sell orders as anxious investors dumped shares in Australia's bluest of blue chip companies.

Mr Robinson said the market was ``incredibly nervous yesterday, trading in fear of the unknown''.

He said unlike other market corrections -- the 1987 stock market collapse, 9/11 terrorist attacks and the Asian flu epidemic -- yesterday's uncertainty went to the ``very heart of the financial system''.

``We've never had the Fed (the US Federal Reserve) take such proactive action in such big numbers to rescue insurance giant American International Group and the Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac mortgage originators.

``We're not out of the woods yet. The bear market is likely to stay with us for the next 18 to 24 months.

``The speed of events has created so much uncertainty in the market that it is trying to second-guess itself, which creates further uncertainty and volatility,'' he said.

Many investors simply lost confidence, forcing their brokers to panic sell, said BBY financial services analyst George Gabriel. ``The size of falls across the financial sector -- Macquarie down 20 per cent; Babcock & Brown down 21 per cent; NAB down 7 per cent; Westpac down 6 per cent -- suggests the markets are in the process of capitulating.

``While capitulation is usually a precursor to the market forming a new lower base, BBY is still not bullish on the basis that seismic risk will overhang the market for some time yet,'' Mr Gabriel said.

Mr Robinson said only gold had the biggest one-day jump with investors turning to gold as a safe commodity during times of uncertainty.

David Iron, director of equity sales trading at ABN Amro, said the fall in the equity market was different from other market corrections because of the ``general lack of understanding of where the risks lie''.

``The number of institutions that have stopped dealing with each other and the number of banks that have stopped dealing with each other is unprecedented.

``The raft of high-quality stock that has been sold down because of rumours and conjecture is unbelievable.''

However, he said market corrections often represented good buying opportunities for the long term. BBY has been bearish about the banking and financial services sector.

Mr Gabriel said: ``We issued a research note entitled `Credit Crisis Tsunami' comparing the current credit crisis to Hurricane Gustav in New Orleans. We stated that New Orleans Mayor Ray Nagin's comments could just as easily apply to banking and financial stocks.

``Ray Nagin said: `You need to be scared. You need to be concerned. And you need to get ... moving out of New Orleans right now. This is the storm of the century'.

``The pace of insolvency, bailout and merger and acquisition activity occurring in today's financial sector is unprecedented in living memory.

``Once venerable institutions have fallen victim to this crisis, Bear Stearns, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch, Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac and AIG, with rumours circulating as to the next possible victim,'' Mr Gabriel said.

urn:contentItem:4P84-VDR0-TXN5-R2HM-00000-00IN BRIEF1995-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10IN BRIEF

CULT LEADER SAW DEATH

BRANCH Davidian leader David Koresh was determined to die in a 1993 confrontation with the FBI at the cult's compound near Waco, Texas, a Texas social worker testified yesterday.

"The (FBI) raid was a mistake. Once it started the fire was inevitable. Once that happened children were going to die," Joyce Sparks said, referring to the use of tear-gas by the FBI.

GAS EVIDENCE

TRACES of VX gas in a Japanese man who died in Osaka in December could corroborate a confession by a leader of the religious cult, AUM Shinrikyo, that he killed the man, police said yesterday.

ATHENS BLAZE

HUNDREDS of people fled their homes in panic yesterday to escape a forest fire near Athens.

FORCED DOWN

A BRITISH Virgin airliner was intercepted by a Russian MiG fighter and forced to land in Moscow yesterday because authorities were unaware that permission to fly over Russia on a new London-Hong Kong route had been given, a British newspaper reported.

MIRACLE HAND

A HUMAN hand, relic of a priest hanged, drawn and quartered during the Reformation 300 years ago, is credited with saving a gravely ill priest in Hereford, England, last week.

PEACE MOVE

RUSSIAN and separatist Chechen negotiators hope to sign an agreement soon to end the bloodshed in breakaway Chechnya.

NUKE DEMAND

US sanctions have so eroded Pakistan's conventional defence capability that it has no option but to speed development of a nuclear weapons program, Pakistan's Senate said in a report yesterday.

BLOODY THREAT

TAMIL separatists have threatened to kill thousands of Muslims unless they flee a town in eastern Sri Lanka by August 1, a police source said yesterday.

KILLER HEAT

PARIS: Temperatures soared to baking point across parts of Europe yesterday, killing at least three people.

Illus: TIME TO COOL OFF: Kaveri and her cub Nina frolic at the Vincennes zoo in suburban Paris yesterday as a heatwave pushes city temperatures to almost 40C.

urn:contentItem:4P7M-CWJ0-TXN5-R2M2-00000-00BUSHFIRES RAVAGE NATIONAL PARK1990-12-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 3BUSHFIRES RAVAGE NATIONAL PARKKAREN DAVEY

HUGE bushfires raged out of control in the Deua National Park, 70km south-east of Canberra, yesterday afternoon.

Department of Bush Fire Services spokeswoman Anne Gittins said: "We're trying to contain the blaze because if it moves into the inaccessible areas of national park we've got Buckleys of controlling it."

Last night fire control co-ordinator and deputy shire president of Tallaganda Shire, John Bunn, said the fire fighting effort was dependent on a change in the weather.

"We're waiting for a southerly change to assist a back-burning operation,"he explained. "But I wouldn't like to be out there.

"My men have been out all night and day, contending with extreme heat and inhospitable country.

"It's bad enough fighting a fire in that country in the daytime, let alone at night."

Elsewhere:

* 11 bushfires broke out in rapid succession on Friday evening, including the Sydney metropolitan areas of Londonderry, Castlereagh and Kemps Creek, near Liverpool.

* A blaze which threatened property in the Tarbay Gully area of the Hawkesbury River was contained by local brigades and National Parks and Wildlife Service officers.

* A major forest fire which started in the Strickland State Forest, near Gosford, had been held behind control lines by late yesterday afternoon.

* A fire at Monday Creek, near Bourke, and a small grass fire at Tarcutta, near Wagga Wagga, had also been contained.

* A grass fire at Wetherill Park in western Sydney was extinguished after an hour by three local units.

Last night the director-general of the Department of Bush Fire Services, Phil Koperberg, warned against any plans for bushwalking and camping until weather conditions improved, and urged residents to undertake property protection measures.

urn:contentItem:49K3-7NB0-01S8-D2BV-00000-00<published>1987-12-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>HERALD BUSINESS; Pg. 18</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Logging may be felled in Borneo</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, WEDNESDAY Indonesia, the world's largest wood exporter, wants timber companies to move out of Borneo because of rapid deforestation, according to the Forestry Minister Mr Sudjarwo.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Mr Sudjarwo said before a cabinet meeting that fires on the island had taken a heavy toll on the 17 million hectares of forest set aside for logging.</p><p>Instead, he said, Irian Jaya, Indonesia's eastern most province, had 41 million hectares of logging forest and almost all of it was unexploited.</p><p> More than 35 fires broke out in Borneo in August and September during a prolonged drought, destroying several thousand hectares of tropical forest.</p><p> A forest fire that burned for nine months in 1982/83 during the last Borneo drought destroyed 3.6 million hectares, an area the size of Taiwan.</p><p> Mr Sudjarwo said the Government was still calculating losses from that fire.</p><p>Indonesia is encouraging the development of Irian Jaya, the western half of the island Indonesia shares with Papua New Guinea. The resource-rich province is sparsely populated and covered with nearly impenetrable jungle.</p><p> Export earnings from the timber industry last year were $A200 billion and it employed 650,000 workers in 1985.</p><p>Indonesia has 144 million hectares of forests, the world's largest after Brazil, encompassing more than half the rain forests in Asia.</p><p> About 60 per cent of Indonesia's timber production is from Borneo, where most of Indonesia's 300 saw mills and 100 plywood factories are also located.</p><p> Mr Sudjarwo said the mills were under utilised and some should now be shifted to Irian Jaya.</p><p> REUTER</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source
