urn:contentItem:5F0H-1FR1-JCM0-63DV-00000-00SA bushfire: Homes lost as Adelaide Hills blaze burns towards townships2015-01-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisSA bushfire: Homes lost as Adelaide Hills blaze burns towards townships

The Adelaide Hills remains under threat tonight as a massive bushfire threatens dozens of communities just 26 kilometres from the city's centre.

A major emergency was earlier declared, with the fire conditions described as the worst since Ash Wednesday in 1983.

Dozens of homes are feared lost and lives remain in danger as the out-of-control fire burns on multiple fronts after an afternoon wind change.

CFS chief officer Greg Nettleton estimated the Sampson Flat fire had burnt more than 11,000 hectares and may not be brought under control until early next week.

"We've got a lot of work to do out there, first of all in controlling the fire and then cleaning up all the insecure edges," he said.

"We'll be working very hard to try and get that fire secured before hot and windy conditions that are anticipated on Wednesday."

Premier Jay Weatherill said, despite cooler conditions, the situation remained "extremely dangerous".

"There should be no sense of relief because the temperatures are somewhat lower or that there are spots of rain about," he said.

Around 300 firefighters supported by 50 appliances were battling the blaze overnight, with 100 personnel and trucks sent from New South Wales to relieve local crews.

"There has been difficulty today in some of the areas in working out exactly where the fire is due to the smoke coverage," Mr Nettleton said.

Mr Eden said 13 firefighters had so far been injured tackling the fires.

"We've been very lucky given the hundreds of people on shift around this very active fire," he said.

"Whilst it's very sad for those that have been impacted by conditions, they are at the minor level of smoke inhalation or burns to a wrist from burning embers.

"We've had no serious or significant injuries, which is a credit to the firefighters and also a credit to the community that we haven't had any fatalities associated with this outbreak."

The fire earlier reached the Kersbrook primary school, with reports flames had also spread to the Cudlee Creek primary school, but the Big Rocking Horse remains unscathed despite suggestions to the contrary on social media.

Roads remain closed around the fire ground and spot fires have been reported outside the main fire zone.

The CFS said Saturday's fire conditions were the worst it had seen since the Ash Wednesday bushfires in 1983.

Seven homes and a number of sheds have been confirmed destroyed, but the actual number remains unknown, with damage assessment teams unable to begin work.

CFS assistant chief officer Rob Sandford said the number of properties lost could number in the dozens.

Kersbrook resident David Miller said he was trying to protect his home when it went up in flames.

"There were two windows up on that side and once the second one went, I couldn't even get inside to get keys for the vehicles," he said.

"That's why I lost the vehicles and the carport. I would be silly if I said [it's] not frightening. It's scary when you hear that fire."

A large number of dogs and cats perished as the fires swept through the Tea Tree Gully Boarding Kennels and Cattery at Inglewood.

The business owners used social media to share the news that, while they managed to save in excess of 40 dogs, no cats survived when the cattery was destroyed.

The owners said they were devastated by the loss of their home, business and people's pets.

"We love all the animals we have in our care and are devastated by this. Our deepest sympathy to all who have suffered a loss," a post on the business' Facebook page said.

SA Water has asked residents to cut down on their water use because of supply issues on the fire front.

"Our problem is that people are still perhaps watering gardens and things like that which aren't essential at the moment," spokesman Steve Rose said.

"There are people in places like Gumeracha and Birdwood that are facing the fire front and need all of the water they can get for their roofs, gutters and everything else to protect their properties."

Meanwhile, the CFS said the threat from a forest fire at Tantanoola in the state's south-east that had burnt up to 700 hectares had reduced.

Around 2,000 firefighters have attended dozens of incidents across South Australia, with some sparked by lightning strikes as storms moved across the state.

Evacuees congregate at relief centres outside fire zone

South Australian police earlier declared the Sampson Flat fire a major emergency, giving authorities the power to forcibly evacuate people or block them from entering the region.

The bushfire is burning freely towards townships and residents across the area are fleeing to safer ground, although some have chosen to stay and defend their homes.

There are relief centres at Golden Grove Recreation Centre on The Golden Way at Golden Grove and at the Willaston Football Club in Gawler.

Police Commissioner Gary Burns said the cause of the fire had not been determined.

"An incinerator is one line of investigation we're looking at," he said.

SA Ambulance earlier said it was treating a 64-year-old man from Inglewood for suspected burns to his throat.

It is believed the man was injured while trying to defend his home.

Another resident in the area, Merv at Cudlee Creek, defended and saved his home but lost several sheds.

"All my work tools and everything have all gone," he said.

"All my wood's gone for the year, but never mind, the house is still there."

Earlier on Saturday, deputy incident controller Ian Tanner said people in the area who are unprepared should voluntarily evacuate if conditions are safe.

"There's not a fire service anywhere in the world that could put this fire out at the moment," he said.

Drop-off points are being set up to allow donations of water and high-energy food for exhausted CFS firefighters.

urn:contentItem:4KBF-WPV0-TXCV-31YB-00000-00DOOM & GLOOM2006-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisWORLDDoom & GloomPg. 10

MATP

DOOM & GLOOM

EIGHT BODIES FOUND IN CARS

BRAZILIAN police found eight bodies in two abandoned cars on the outskirts of Rio de Janeiro yesterday.

The bodies of people aged 20-25 show signs of torture and bullet wounds typical of executions. ''They are drug traffickers involved in a turf war,'' Rio Police Sergeant Luis Bensaba said. Police believe the slain belong to a gang from the Monkeys' Hill slum, which has been fighting a rival group from the Sao Joao slum over drugs sales.

RUSSIAN TROOPS ATTACKED

SEVEN Russian troops were killed and 25 wounded yesterday when gunmen attacked their military column in Chechnya, Interfax news agency reported.

Sources said the column was southeast of Grozny.

Rebel attacks are frequent and police and soldiers die every week. In recent years, the separatist war in Chechnya has evolved into a general Islamist uprising.

HAND CART BOMB INJURES 10

A BOMB hidden in a cart exploded today in a crowded intersection of downtown Kabul, injuring 10 people.

And five Afghan labourers were ambushed and fatally shot on their way to a US military base in east Afghanistan.

The attacks come amid an upsurge of violence by Taliban-led rebels, 12 of whom were killed.

The bomb had been planted in a hand cart behind a car, police official Mohammed Nabi said. The explosion took place at a busy intersection near the presidential palace.

SECOND HIGH PROFILE ABDUCTION

AN Iraqi deputy minister and his 19 bodyguards were kidnapped by gunmen in broad daylight today and held for 10 hours before being released.

The US military said today it killed an al-Qaida operative suspected of bombing a Baghdad market last week that left 66 people dead.

Deputy Electricity Minister Raad al-Hareth and his bodyguards were in four cars when they were ambushed by gunmen wearing uniforms in Talbiyah, an official said.

TOWN FORCED TO FLEE FIRE

ABOUT 4000 people were yesterday forced to flee a raging forest fire that threatened to cut off their only escape from a small mining town in western Canada.

Residents of Tumbler Ridge in British Columbia were ordered to leave as the blaze burned to within 12km, provincial fire department spokeswoman Radha Fisher said.

Most headed to two nearby towns, she said.

''The fire raced almost 16km in just four hours,'' Fisher said. ''It was originally caused by lightning. The reason it's now so big is that conditions are dry.''

DUBLIN AIRPORT BOMB SCARE

POLICE ordered the emergency evacuation of Dublin International Airport yesterday after a man claiming to have a bomb in a suitcase was arrested in the arrivals hall.

Ireland's national police force, the Garda Siochana, said several units and the Irish army bomb squad were sent to the airport, 15km north of central Dublin. No explosive device was found.

Dublin Airport Authority spokeswoman Siobhan Moore said all travellers and staff had been evacuated.

urn:contentItem:4T4W-TW70-TX5N-01CY-00000-00Olympics2008-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisDISCOVERYPg. 23OlympicsDISCOVERY A GEELONG ADVERTISER NIE PROJECT

The Olympic Games begin on August 8, 2008 at 8.08.08pm (local Beijing time)

In Chinese culture eight is a lucky number, a symbol of prosperity and good fortune. The slogan for the games is One World, One Dream. The Games symbolise the ideal of peace and humanity, a dream shared by all.

The Olympic rings

The Olympic rings are the official symbol of the Olympics. There are five interlacing coloured rings: blue, yellow, black, green, and red set upon a white background. The rings represent the union of the five continents and the meeting of athletes from around the world at the Olympic Games. The colours were chosen because at least one of these five colours is found within the flag of every nation

The Olympic emblem

Every emblem of the Olympics tells a story. Dancing Beijing is a Chinese Seal part of an ancient tradition and engraved by hand, seals are used to reproduce the same character by printing.The Beijing 2008 Olympic Games emblem Dancing Beijing combines the tradition of the Chinese seal, the art of calligraphy and the theme of sport. Against a red background a moving silhouette is shown running in celebration of victory.

The torch

The Olympic Torch carries the Olympic flame. A new torch is created for each edition of the Games to represent the culture of the host country.

The Beijing torch is designed in the shape of a curved scroll, referring to paper, one of the most important Chinese inventions. The lucky cloud, motif is an ancient Chinese decoration. The image of the lucky cloud means harmony.

The mascots

Five fuwa (Children bringing good luck) are the official mascots of the Beijing Games. The fuwa are inspired by the colours of the Olympic Rings and popular animals in China: the fish, panda, Tibetan antelope and the swallow. One of the mascots represents the Olympic flame rather than an animal. Their headpieces represent elements of nature: sea, forest, fire, earth and sky.

Beibei: In Chinese traditional art, fish and water designs symbolise prosperity. BeiBei is good at water sports and represents the blue Olympic ring.

Jingjing: Jingjing, the panda, represents the harmonious relationship between man and nature. An athlete noted for his strength, Jingjing represents the black Olympic ring.

Huanhuan: A child of fire, Huanhuan symbolises the Olympic flame and passion for sport and excels at all ball games and represents the red Olympic ring.

Yingying: The Tibetan antelope reflects the vastness of the country and carries the blessing of good health. Strong in athletics, Yingying represents the yellow Olympic ring.

Nini: Kite-flying is popular amongst Chinese children. The golden winged swallow is a traditional kite shape. Nini symbolises good luck. She is good at gymnastics and represents the green Olympic ring.

The medals

The obverse (front) face of the Beijing medals show Nike, Greek symbol of victory with the Panathinaikos stadium in Athens, venue for the first modern Olympic Games in 1896, in the background.

The reverse (back) face is inlaid with a jade disc. Jade is a precious stone and important part of Chinese culture, representing beauty and excellence in all things. The medal hook is inspired by the dragon motif, the oldest example of animal symbolism in China.

urn:contentItem:4P13-32V0-TXN5-R3BF-00000-00Cool world2005-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisSUNDAY LIFEPg. 34Cool worldHomeWords and styling Megan Morton

It may be small but this apartment is inspired by the grandeur of the great outdoors.

Who lives here? Caroline West, magazine art director.

Describe your personal style. "Well, there is my obvious obsession with 'Canadiana' - inspired by trips to the incredible snow-covered Canadian Rockies - including a precious Econolite [an illuminated revolving forest fire with bear diorama lamp], snow scenes and lots of bears, and an ever-growing collection of Hornsea china from the '50s and '60s. I guess you could call my style contemporary retro."

How long has it taken you to pull your apartment together? "I've lived here for 18 months but it felt like home after the initial six months. I'm always adding little things here and there to brighten the place up and add interest."

Where did you find your inspiration? "The 1950s lounge suite was my main purchase and I found it then influenced the look of the apartment."

What were your home priorities? "I was after a comfortable retreat."

Did you enlist professional help? "No, but friends and colleagues have given me such beautiful photos and art over the years [Lucy Culliton, Warwick Orme, Martyn Thompson] and this has helped me pull the apartment's look together."

Best thing about living here? "Not having a car, living in Kirribilli [on Sydney's lower north shore] is perfect - it's so close to the harbour and the city. I walk to work every day."

Favourite room? "I don't have a favourite room. I like them all - all three of them, that is! In this small apartment, it's the beautiful windows and their deep sills I like the most."

Decor secret? "I love poking around in op-shops - for more Hornsea pieces - and toy shops for bears to add to the collection."

urn:contentItem:4P37-23C0-TX5J-H360-00000-00Fires rage as Greece swelters - Longest heatwave a killer2007-07-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 45Fires rage as Greece swelters - Longest heatwave a killer

ATHENS: Hundreds of firefighters and troops yesterday battled a forest fire on a mountain overlooking Athens as Greece's longest heatwave on record claimed three new victims.

And in the US, residents sifted through the ashes of homes lost in a California bushfire.

A cloud of smoke blocked out the sun over the Greek capital and ash rained down on some parts as 200 firefighters, 300 troops and 12 planes battled firefronts on Mt Parnitha.

The heatwave that has seared much of southern Europe since mid-June has killed 12 people in Greece and more than 50 in other countries.

The Greek Government said it had ''successfully handled a difficult task'' as there had been no victims from an all-night battle to contain the mountain fire. But it was heavily criticised for failing to adequately protect one of the few green areas around the heavily polluted Greek capital.

''Athens has lost a valuable ecosystem,'' said the park's head warden, George Amorgianiotis.

A military radar station, a casino and summer camps on Mt Parnitha were evacuated on Friday. But the fire department said homes in the area were no longer threatened.

By late yesterday, the fire had moved on to a ridge several kilometres long about 30km northwest of Athens.

It had crept up to the mountain from the west, where a blaze raged since Wednesday. Authorities were blamed for failing to predict its course.

''We fumbled that one,'' Greek Public Order Minister Vyron Polydoras said, admitting the fire department erred in trying to avoid dropping water near power lines in the area.

Polydoras has suggested some of the fires that have been started in recent days were the work of arsonists.

Fires continued to rage in Schimatari on the Gulf of Evia, in two separate areas in the central region of Larissa, and the picturesque central region of Pelion.

Fires in more than 100 sites across Greece since Wednesday broke out after a nine-day heatwave with temperatures of more than 40C described by authorities as the longest recorded in the country.

In the US, people who lost their homes and belongings to a devastating California bushfire were briefly allowed to return as authorities declared the blaze mostly contained.

With evacuation orders lifted in many parts of Lake Tahoe, residents of the area where 254 houses were destroyed were yesterday given an hour to sift through the wreckage under the eyes of a police escort.

Keith Cooney saw his home engulfed in flames on a news broadcast on Sunday and came back to find only a bent metal garage door standing.

''I gotta dig through this. This is going to be unbelievable,'' Cooney said as the wind blew through the blackened, charred leaves of several young aspen trees in the remains of his front yard.

By yesterday the blaze was 70 per cent contained after charring 1250ha, according to US Forest Service incident commander Rich Hawkins.

urn:contentItem:4SVB-JSM0-TXN5-S1FW-00000-00Climate change threatens havoc for Western Port2008-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Climate change threatens havoc for Western PortMathew Murphy, Energy Reporter

VICTORIA'S Western Port region is at risk of experiencing more bushfires, rising sea levels, higher temperatures and the once-in-a-century storm becoming an annual occurrence unless measures are taken to combat climate change.

The grim warning forms part of a comprehensive two-year study by the CSIRO and economists Marsden Jacob Associates, set to be released today.

The report, obtained by The Age, found that a rise in sea levels would "undoubtedly" affect Western Port's low-lying coastline, with the townships on Phillip Island, Tooradin, Warneet and Hastings most at risk.

The impact on the local economy, tourist attractions including surrounding beaches, property and human health could be substantial, it warns.

Fears have also been expressed for the local penguin population, one of Victoria's most popular tourist attractions, with a separate report being undertaken to determine the risks of climate change to the penguin colony.

In the worst-case scenario, the study predicts temperature increases of 1.1 degrees by 2030 and 3.5 degrees by 2070, with heat-related human deaths set to rise to 53 a year by 2100.

"The Western Port region is significantly exposed to climate extremes and natural hazards such as storm surges and coastal inundation, floods, bushfires and extreme temperatures. These hazards are expected to increase in frequency and/or severity," the report says.

"(It will have direct impact on) land use and management, damages and maintenance costs to public and private property and infrastructure, human health and water availability."

The report, which was funded by the federal and state governments and has received local government input, will be used by all levels of government to formulate climate-change policy. It comes a week before the Federal Government's climate-change adviser, Ross Garnaut, releases his draft report into emissions trading.

One of the report authors, Dr Kathy McInnes, said the low-lying Western Port region had been selected because it was particularly vulnerable. Many of the findings would be relevant to other coastal areas.

"This information will help prioritise the areas of the community that are particularly at risk," she said.

The report also projects that:

· By 2070, extreme rainfall will increase by up to 70%, depending on location. However, average rainfall is expected to decline by up to 8% by 2030 and up to 23% by 2070.

· Sea levels will rise by up to 0.17 metres by 2030 and up to 0.49 metres by 2070, with vulnerable areas in Western Port to increase by up to 15% by 2030 and 63% by 2070. More than 2000 individuals, more than 1000 dwellings and property worth about $780 million will be affected.

· The number of "very high" and "extreme" forest fire days in the Western Port region will increase by one or two days by 2030 and two to seven days by 2050.

Greg Hunt, executive officer of the Western Port Greenhouse Alliance, which commissioned the report, said it was not designed to be alarmist.

"What this shows is that we need leadership from all three tiers of government. We are going to need some engineering solutions, and our engineers are looking at that," he said.

urn:contentItem:47RT-34R0-015H-505X-00000-00<published>2003-01-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Inferno toll climbs  ;<br/>Four houses destroyed as blazes rage out of control</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BUSHFIRES continued to threaten homes around Australia last night with the worst in Victoria.</p><p nitf:lede="true">   The fire in the state's southeast has destroyed four houses and continues to rage out of control. Authorities believe it was deliberately lit.</p><p> Country Fire Authority chief fire officer Russell Rees said three fires began in quick succession, destroying four houses at Yackan- dandah, Stanley and in the Indigo Valley.</p><p>   "The origin of these fires is suspicious . . . and is being investigated by police," Mr Rees told reporters.</p><p>   More than 20,000ha has now been burned at Eldorado, and up to 4000ha was razed in Stanley, with the flames racing through grassland, scrub, plantation pines and box ironbark country. However, Mr Rees said that given there were 130 houses directly in the path of the fires, the efforts of firefighters and the community had worked well.</p><p>   "It's outstanding that the losses were so small," he said.</p><p>   By mid-afternoon yesterday, the Eldorado and Stanley fires had slowed along the front- lines and firefighters were controlling them from the flanks.</p><p>   Relief centres have been established at Wodonga, Chiltern, Beechworth, Myrtleford and Bright for residents who have fled their homes.</p><p>   Mr Rees said firefighters were working frantically ahead of forecast extreme conditions over the weekend.</p><p>   He said that, with conditions so dry after five years of drought, the fires were continuing to burn regardless of the temperature or wind.</p><p>   "There has been 15 days of solid fires. In my view there is no end in sight," said Mr Rees.</p><p>   Meanwhile, exhausted crews in Victoria's northeastern alpine areas, where lightning strikes started a series of fires earlier this month, were yesterday relieved with reinforcements arriving from around the state.</p><p>   A team of forest fire experts from New Zealand had also been deployed to the Gippsland fires near Omeo, which were burning through dense, rugged country.</p><p>The threat to the township of Bright eased overnight and firefighters were able to hold control lines around the blaze, now burning on a 100km front.</p><p>   In Canberra, the immediate fire threat eased as cooler conditions and more favourable winds kept fires to the north and south of the city at bay. Suburbs in the north of the nation's capital remain on high alert.</p><p>   In NSW, firefighters yesterday took advantage of milder weather to try to contain 30 blazes burning out of control across the state.</p><p>   NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman John Winter said 1500 personnel were deployed to work on 71 fires yesterday.</p><p>* A city ablaze: Focus, Page 23</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:52W9-K1N1-JC0X-K31Y-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 07:00 May 172011-05-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 07:00 May 17

  HIGHLIGHTS WORLD (ATTN EDITORS)
Highlights of the AAP world file since 20:00
IMF chief pleads not guilty, denied bail
   NEW YORK, May 16 AFP - IMF chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn has denied the sexual assault and attempted rape of a New York hotel chambermaid on Monday but has been refused bail and ordered to remain behind bars pending trial. (US STRAUSSKHAN Update sent at 03:19, 714 words.)


Irish republicans issue London bomb threat
   LONDON, May 16 AFP - London police received a bomb threat from Irish republicans, on the eve of an historic trip by Queen Elizabeth II to Ireland and a week before US President Barack Obama visits the British capital. (UK TERROR 2nd Update sent at 23:31, 563 words.)
Gaddafi arrest warrant sought by ICC
   THE HAGUE, May 16 AFP - The International Criminal Court's prosecution applied on Monday for a warrant for Muammar Gaddafi's arrest for crimes against humanity, a day after the Libyan strongman's regime offered a truce in return for a halt to NATO-led air strikes. (WARCRIMES GADDAFI sent at 04:16, 743 words.)
Space shuttle Endeavour blasts off
   CAPE CANAVERAL, Florida, May 16 AFP - The space shuttle Endeavour blasted off Monday toward the International Space Station on the penultimate flight for the US shuttle program. (US SHUTTLE sent at 01:43, 692 words.)
Mubarak's wife pledges assets amid probe
   CAIRO, May 16 AFP - The wife of ousted Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak on Monday pledged to hand over her money and property to the state, days after she was ordered detained on corruption charges, the official MENA news agency reported. (EGYPT MUBARAK sent at 06:32, 520 words.)
Flight data from Rio-Paris crash 'intact'
   PARIS, May 16 AFP - All flight data from the Air France jet that crashed into the Atlantic in 2009 have been preserved in the plane's retrieved black box recorders, French aviation authorities say. (FRANCE BRAZIL sent at 04:42, 427 words.)
Imam pleads not guilty to terror charge
   MIAMI, May 16 AFP - An elderly Miami imam pleaded not guilty in US federal court on Monday to charges of supporting the Pakistani Taliban and was ordered held without bail, his lawyer said. (US TALIBAN sent at 07:55, 244 words.)
Trump says no to presidential run
   NEW YORK, May 16 AP - After months of flirting with politics, Donald Trump said he won't run for president, choosing to stick with hosting The Celebrity Apprentice over a bid for the Republican nomination. (US TRUMP Update sent at 07:50, 615 words.)
Clinton to visit Pakistan but no date set
   WASHINGTON, May 16 AFP - US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton will visit Pakistan for "strategic" talks following the US raid that killed al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden, but no date has been set, a spokesman said. (US CLINTON sent at 04:55, 207 words.)
US drone attacks kill seven in Pakistan
   MIRANSHAH, Pakistan, May 16 AFP - Two US drone strikes targeting a militant compound and a vehicle in Pakistan's lawless tribal district of North Waziristan have killed at least seven militants on Monday. (PAKISTAN DRONE Update sent at 03:34, 528 words.)
Six die, two wounded in Iraqi violence
   BAGHDAD, May 16 AFP - Six people have been killed in a spate of attacks in Iraq on Monday, including a Christian whose body was mutilated, while two Norwegians hurt in a Baghdad bomb blast are among at least 16 injured, officials say. (IRAQ UNREST sent at 02:25, 491 words.)
Fire razes Canadian town, 7000 evacuated
   OTTAWA, May 16 AFP - A wildfire engulfed the town of Slave Lake in western Canada on Monday, forcing the evacuation of its 7,000 residents at the start of the forest fire season. (CANADA FIRES sent at 02:23, 155 words.)
Abusers must face justice, says Vatican
   VATICAN CITY, May 16 AFP - Priests suspected of child-abuse sex crimes should be turned over to the authorities and face legal action, the Vatican says in a letter to bishops on anti-pedophilia guidelines. (VATICAN ABUSE Wrap sent at 21:58, 344 words.)

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Soviets ask for time to pull out</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MOSCOW The Soviet Union wanted Prague to give it more time to withdraw the 75,000 Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia, East European diplomats said today.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> They said the Soviet side made its stand clear when a second round of talks on withdrawal opened in Moscow today.</p><p>At the same time a Prague spokesman, in a Moscow interview with Czechoslovak Radio, rejected Soviet criticism of a "troops out" demonstration in Prague yesterday and said the Soviet Union was causing tension by delaying the withdrawal.</p><p> In a first round of talks in Prague last month, Czechoslovakia's reformist government told Soviet negotiators it wanted the troops, in the country since the Warsaw Pact invasion of 1968, to leave this year.</p><p> Czechoslovak officials say they have no doubt the Soviet leadership has taken the decision to withdraw.But according to the East European diplomats, Moscow argues that it needs more time to provide housing and social services for the returning officers and men and their families, whose numbers will be swollen by others to be withdrawn from Hungary.</p><p> Czechoslovak sources said they feared public anger over the troops could rise after an explosion at a Soviet arsenal, 300km east of Prague yesterday, causing a forest fire.</p><p> The Czechoslovak state nes agency CTK said today the massive blast was caused by careless handling of ammunition by Soviet soldiers.</p><p> The explosion happened when soldiers were using 12kg of TNT to destroy 500 anti-tank grenades and 20kg of gunpowder, CTK said.</p><p> No one was hurt in the explosion, at the Libava base,, but windows were blown out in buildings in nearby villages and red dust rained down on the area.</p><p> Defence Ministry spokesman Stanislav Pohoral said Soviet soliders had been reponsible for "gross violation of safety regulations".</p><p> REUTER, AP</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5K92-KJT1-DYTG-208G-00000-00'I felt like I was living in a pressure cooker'2016-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisAPg. F012'I felt like I was living in a pressure cooker'The Canberra Times

MUSIC 'I felt like I was living in a pressure cooker' James Blake explains why he's learnt to let go, writes TIM BYRON.

" I just sat there, not really sure where my life had gone.

JAMES BLAKE James Blake at Splendour in the Grass in 2013. He is returning to Australia to play the event again this weekend.PHOTO: RACHEL MURDOLO L ondon-born singer-songwriter- producer James Blake has a voice you suspect would sound sad singing about sunshine, rainbows and lollipops, and his music has the kind of languid electronics that feel positively icy. His most recent album, The Colour in Anything, had critics using phrases such as "impressionistic melancholy" to describe the album's emotional palette.

Perhaps surprisingly then, Blake comes across as positively upbeat. "I'm in a good place," he says of his current mental state. "It feels a lot easier to wake up every day and look forward to what it brings."

Of course, it doesn't hurt that a lot of big names want to work with him right now.

Recently, Blake found himself in Kanye West's studio, as the rapper talked to Madonna on the phone. "I just sat there, not really sure where my life had gone," says Blake, "kind of wondering what they were talking about."

At some point in the conversation, Madonna wanted to talk to him. "It's one of those moments where someone's pointing over to you and you're like, 'me?' and looking around to see if they mean someone else."

So what do you say when Madonna phones Kanye then wants to say hello to you? Blake's answer was perhaps inevitable: "Yeah, hi! Oh, thank you. Uh, OK,bye!"

"It was very sweet," he says. However, he demurs at the suggestion it must be odd to hang out with extroverts such as Kanye and Madonna, as a person who is a bit introverted and self-conscious.

"To be honest, I'm not really. I'm a very social person, and I'm not afraid of anybody. And I'm completely happy to engage on whatever level."

Blake, now 27 years old, was born into a musical family; his father played guitar in 1970s prog rock bands. After finishing school, Blake completed a degree in popular music from Goldsmiths University of London; he even submitted his 2010 Klavierwerke EP as a uni assessment.

He first toured Australia in 2011 after releasing his self-titled debut album. "His single The Wilhelm Scream was the first track we played," says Triple J presenter Linda Marigliano, "and the one that really introduced him to his audience."

In 2011, Blake played Marrickville's intimate Factory Theatre. He won the UK's prestigious Mercury Music Prize in 2013 for his album Overgrown, and now he's playing at the Hordern Pavilion to 10 times as many people.

What's more, Blake's distinctive sound - which Marigliano describes as "true delicacy in his tinkering melodies sitting atop some spectacularly fat bass grooves, [with] organic and electronic elements married together in real harmony" - has had a profound influence on mainstream pop music. Recent No.1 singles such as Zayn's Pillowtalk or Gnash's I Hate You, I Love You would sound quite different without Blake's musical impact. No wonder he ends up at Kanye's studio talking to Madonna.

Yet Blake is dismissive when asked what his distinctive sound means to him. "I think it now means absolutely nothing. As it crops up in other places, it loses its currency. Now, I don't have any intention of adhering to that sound."

Blake's newly found inner peace, seemingly, is not the result of success, but something simpler: letting go.

Until The Colour in Anything, his guiding ethos was do-it-yourself. Between the melodies, the lyrics, the beats, the glitchy electronic sounds, the vocals and the gospel piano, previous records have been all Blake, all the time - he even engineered and mixed the albums himself. However, the pressure of doing it all himself was starting to get to him.

"I just felt like I was living in a pressure cooker, and my head space was getting worse and worse," he says. "I had so many nagging worries when I was making the record ... I felt like I wasn't progressing at the rate I wanted to, and I was kind of in a rut."

He decided to go for a different approach on The Colour in Anything: collaboration. Part of the album was recorded with superstar producer Rick Rubin on the seafront at Malibu, which Blake describes one of the most beautiful places on Earth. They spent the time "just exploring music".

"It really was one of the most defining moments in mylife," Blake says.

"It really does absolve you of a lot of pressure when you start to let other people help you."

He is careful, though, to clarify the nature of the help he needed. Most producers make beats and play keyboards, he says. "But I didn't want anyone to get involved that way. I didn't need it.

I can do it myself, and I didn't feel like I needed that kind of hands-on help. Which is where Rick came in."

Rubin - the producer behind albums such as Johnny Cash's American Recordings, the Red Hot Chili Peppers' Blood Sugar Sex Majik, and Slayer's Reign in Blood - is the kind of guy who comes across as more of a life coach than a maker of beats.

"What I really needed was guidance," Blake says. Rubin is "really good at mysteriously finding the best in somebody and allowing them to pursue it".

When the guy with the hip, influential sound decides he's open to collaboration, it's no surprise that big names line up to work with him, from Kanye to R&B singers such as Beyonce and Frank Ocean.

Justin Vernon of Bon Iver, who appears on I Need a Forest Fire on The Colour in Anything, tweeted that the song came from "wonderful accidents and good friendship".

Blake also prominently appears on Beyonce's Forward (which he also co-wrote), from her recent album Lemonade. "I didn't consider it something I would have a lot of control over," says Blake of his initial worries about the collaboration. "But in the end, what I did was used with such respect that it gave me a reason to want to go and do it again. I felt really comfortable in that position.

"Despite me using my own lyrics, and despite it not being the most conventional piece of music, she put it on her record, and I think that it really works. I think that they have a good ear, and they got it right."

Blake says he tries not to let preconceptions get in the way of his work. "You know, I don't see people as their avatar. I just respond to what they are in person, and that's the only way you can treat anybody. I think that extends to everybody, from the doorman to the person who owns the venue, to the cleaner, to the band."

For Blake, Kanye West's energy is very positive. "Every time I leave the room after having spoken to him, I'm galvanised and excited. And I can't put my finger on exactlywhy that is, but I think that's a really fantastic quality."

So Kanye's not the narcissist his public persona suggests?

"He's just a man with a lot of ideas. You know, I think the people around him are panning for gold, but I think that there is a lot of gold that comes from him ... there's a reason why he has made so many great albums."

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NJS0-TXN5-S0S8-00000-00Families evacuated as firefighters battle blaze1998-02-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Families evacuated as firefighters battle blazeANDREA CARSON and CLAIRE MILLER

Primary schoolchildren in the Western District town of Simpson were yesterday ordered to stay at school as a bushfire raced towards their bus route.

The fire burnt 1200 hectares of bush and farmland.

The 20 schoolchildren were collected after the wind changed and sent the fire in the opposite direction.

About six families living within a seven-kilometre radius of the fire's path were evacuated as firefighters battled the blaze, fanned by winds gusting to 60kmh.

The fire front was at its most threatening near the Timboon-Cobden road. Families were evacuated to nearby Carpendeit.

The fire burned out of control for about seven hours, destroying a shed and threatening 15 farmhouses near Bungador, 10 kilometres north of Simpson. Police feared that an unoccupied house had been lost to the fire.

The fire, first seen in the Jancourt flora and fauna reserve at midday, was burning between Colac and Camperdown.

Strong winds sparked scores of spot fires on private farmland in the Bungador district, a Department of Natural Resources and Environment planning officer said.

Mr Fabian Crowe said the main fire front was burning through the fauna reserve, fuelled by stringybark forest.

More than 250 CFA and department firefighters using equipment, including 12 aircraft, were sent to the fire.

More than 40 spot fires destroyed fences, a farm shed and pasture.

Mr Crowe said the cause of the blaze was unknown, but lightning had been ruled out. "It doesn't appear to be caused by the hand of nature," he said.

A CFA spokesman at Simpson, Mr Lex De Man, said the firefighters would work throug the night.

He said fire crews from neighboring brigades could relieve their colleagues.

Earlier, police closed roads around the fire and assured Geelong residents that thick smoke in the city was from the Colac fire, more than 100 kilometres away.

Photo: Forest ablaze: A helicopter dumps water on the forest fire at Jancourt as it burned out of control yesterday. More than 250 firefighters and 12 aircraft were sent to combat the fire. The cause of the blaze was unknown. Picture: Damian White.

urn:contentItem:3S8G-D2M0-0048-T1JT-00000-00<published>1998-03-20T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: UP TO 1,000 FIRES RAGING IN INDONESIAN BORNEO</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SAMARINDA, Indonesia, March 20 AFP - Up to 1,000 fires were raging in the Indonesian province of East Kalimantan today and the situation was set to deteriorate dramatically as a long drought drags on, firefighters and officials said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Dozens of the fires had been deliberately lit by farmers and plantation and timber firms, sending sparks and hot ash across the province's rugged jungle and forest canopy to start fresh blazes elsewhere, they added.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "It is much worse than last year and it is getting even worse," said Hartmut Abberger, of the German-funded Integrated Forest Fire Management Project in the provincial capital of Samarinda.</p><p>"When anyone starts a fire now, it is almost impossible to control," he added, saying his organisation's latest data gathered from satellite images showed more than 800 fires were burning in the province on the island of Borneo.</p><p> A government forestry official here, who declined to be named, said the situation was "hopeless" and that official figures showed up to 1,000 fires were burning, ranging from small outbreaks to large blazes more than two kilometres wide.</p><p> There were believed to be other fires in remote inland areas but access was diffult and communication links almost non-existent, he said.</p><p> Fires continued to burn in the Bukit Suharto forest area some 70 kilometres south of here today, where they have razed up to 3,000 hectares over the past two weeks officials said.</p><p> The fires were believed to have been started by a farmer who wanted to clear land for a new peppercorn field, Abberger said.</p><p> "He apparently just lost control."</p><p> Scores of fires were also raging in the Kutai national park, some 80 kilometres north of Samarinda, with most of the blazes concentrated around the area's sole major road. Officials said this indicated they had been deliberately lit and added the fires had sparked new blazes within the park which could not easily be reached.</p><p> The fires were now spread over some 200 square kilometres and were sending haze across the province, reducing visibility and blocking out the sun.</p><p>AFP  ts<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S8G-D2M0-0048-T1JT-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="353"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:457Y-S900-0197-52WW-00000-00<published>1998-02-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 6</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Kalimantan fires 'too big to fight'</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIRES raging in the Indonesian province of East Kalimantan were too big and widespread to contain and the situation would only worsen as a prolonged drought dragged on, the head of a fire-fighting project said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "It is really bad," the chief of the German-funded Integrated Forest Fire Management Project, Ludwig Schindler, said on Monday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "The area is completely covered with haze. There is no way to fly. Visibility is down to 300 metres.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP </p></bodyText></section><p>"These fires have escalated to the extent that makes it impossible, or economically impossible, to put them out.</p><p>The only thing that could help now is rain." Mr Schindler was speaking from the southern Sumatran city of Bandar Lampung where he is training military officers how to teach their men to fight fires.</p><p> Mr Schindler said the fires were raging in a 250km band straddling the Mahakam River in central East Kalimantan, one of the provinces in the Indonesian part of the island of Borneo.</p><p> Satellites had detected between 300 and 500 "hot spots" in the area before vision became hampered by the worsening haze in recent days.</p><p>A "hot spot" is an area of 1km square, depicted on satellite images as a single pixel, where fire has been detected.</p><p> Mr Schindler said the fires had not reached the disastrous level of last year, when choking haze from Indonesia billowed over much of South-East Asia.</p><p> The 1997 fires caused respiratory illness, disrupted air travel and hurt tourism. Seasonal rain doused most of the fires late last year.</p><p> Mr Schindler's group has accused timber and plantation companies of starting the fires to clear land. More than a dozen companies are now under investigation by the Indonesian authorities.</p><p> The group is also critical of the handling of last year's crisis.</p><p> In a report on the 1997 fires released last week, the group said: "The general situation can be described with Indonesia not being able to overcome its own bureaucracy and the international community being absolutely helpless and wasting money for the sake of having done something." </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:3RKX-XVT0-0048-T1R3-00000-00<published>1997-12-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: ASEAN ADOPTS BLUEPRINT TO BATTLE HAZE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SINGAPORE, Dec 23 AFP - ASEAN environment ministers and senior officials today adopted a plan to prevent a recurrence of the haze that enveloped the region this year and made tens of thousands ill.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> ASEAN member countries would try to prevent brush and forest fires, establish mechanisms to monitor the blazes and strengthen regional fire-fighting capabilities, officials said at the end of a meeting here .</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "With the regional haze action plan in place, ASEAN will be in a better position to address the problem of smoke haze," Singapore Environment Minister Yeo Cheow Tong told reporters after the two-day conference.</p><p>Officials said Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore would take the lead. "We expect the three lead countries to do their utmost to make sure the time frame for implementation is being complied with," Yeo said.</p><p> Smoky haze from raging fires in Indonesia which began in August and lasted until November generated air pollution and an outbreak of respiratory diseases affecting tens of thousands in the region.</p><p> Reduced visibility caused a series of fatal accidents and kept thousands of tourists away. Most blazes were started deliberately to clear land.</p><p> The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) comprises Brunei, Burma, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.</p><p> Yeo said Indonesia would lead the effort in honing regional fire-fighting capabilities while Malaysia would play a key role in the implementing preventative measures.</p><p>Singapore would help gauge weather patterns through the ASEAN specialised meteorological centre there.</p><p> ASEAN officials would meet by next February to monitor progress in carrying out the plan. A month later each member should have submitted an inventory on land and forest fire fighting capability and formulated individual programs for strengthening such capability.</p><p> Regional weather experts declared the haze over at the end of November with the coming of the northeast monsoon and its accompanying rain.</p><p> Poor visibility caused by the haze was partly blamed for the September 26 crash of a Garuda Airlines jet in Sumatra that killed 234 people.</p><p>AFP  ts<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3RKX-XVT0-0048-T1R3-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="366"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:457Y-NYX0-0197-51KK-00000-00<published>1997-12-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Dry grass build-up, El Nino fuel a fiery summer </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ASA WAHLQUIST and DAVID McKENZIE</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A LONG build-up of dry ground cover and the El Nino effect could combine to give Australia one of its worst bushfire summers in a decade.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The Bureau of Meteorology predicted yesterday the bushfire danger will increase during the next few months, and the CSIRO warned dry weather in Victoria and wet conditions in western NSW and South Australia would contribute to a serious fire risk this summer.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> In its latest rainfall outlook, the bureau warned the El Nino indicators remained "very strong" and should persist until at least mid-summer, putting water supplies in southern Australia under pressure..</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Phil Cheney, of the CSIRO's bushfire behaviour and management unit, said Sydney faced a bad fire season because the city had had 10 years with only one big burn.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>"Only '94 produced a big fire season and the others were pretty mild, with summer rainfalls closing off the season early.</p><p>People get lulled into a false sense of security," he said.</p><p> Above average spring rainfall west of the Great Dividing Range in NSW and in the State's north had resulted in abundant grass growth. "In areas like the Pilliga Scrub the leaf litter is fairly scattered. The presence of grass contributes to the severity of the forest fire," Mr Cheney said.</p><p> There was a serious fire risk in the southern mountains of NSW, running through the mountain forests in central Victoria, over to the Grampians and perhaps down as far as Mount Gambier in South Australia.</p><p> Victoria has had below average rainfall for the past year, with a particularly dry spring. While the NSW fire season typically ends with summer rain, Victoria has drier summers and its fire season can extend until April.</p><p> "It will be a pretty hot, dry season," Mr Cheney said. "The fuels are ready to burn."</p><p> In South Australia, above average rainfall means there is a good crop of grass, and as it dries off, there will be a severe risk.</p><p> South of Perth, below average spring rainfall has left the forests "pretty dry".</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4586-P1D0-0197-F00C-00000-00<published>1998-01-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Fire heroes' family calls for support</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>HARRIS S</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE children of two critically injured bush fire fighters yesterday called for greater recognition of the heroism of "ordinary people risking their lives to keep us safe".</p><p nitf:lede="true">Gale Pritchett and her husband Frank are battling for their lives after being trapped fighting a horror New Year's blaze in the Southern Highlands of New South Wales.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Mrs Pritchett's daughter Kim, 19, and 21-year-old son Simon issued an impassioned plea for support for the Rural Fire Service.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>More young people should put down their computer games and join the brigade, while governments should recognise firefighters' efforts with "some small token", they said.</p><p>It was Gale Pritchett's dedication to the Southern Highlands hamlet of Wingello which saw her respond to a New Year's Day fire call together with husband Frank.</p><p>And it is this same sense of society which, according to her children, makes both of them heroic.</p><p>"It is a different type of love. They risked their lives," Simon said.</p><p>"Every time that beeper goes off you don't know if you are going to come back . . . it's the risk you take."</p><p>Kim and Simon are also members of the bush fire brigade.</p><p>Today Frank and Gale Pritchett lie critically injured in separate hospital intensive care wards, survivors of a forest fire trap which killed one of their closest mates David Quinlivan and seriously injured five Wingello Rural Fire Service Brigade colleagues.</p><p>Since New Year's Day Kim and Simon have been commuting from their mother's bedside in the intensive care unit of Sydney's Royal North Shore Hospital to their stepfather at Westmead, in Sydney's west.</p><p>"I keep telling mum, 'Come on hurry up and get just a little bit better and then you can both be together'," Kim said.</p><p>"She can't respond but we know she can hear us."</p><p>Simon tells stories of his own about his nine-month old daughter Jacquelyn _ a much loved first grandchild.</p><p>Frank and Gale, who have been married barely a year, met at a bush fire brigade function shortly after Gale's divorce.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>NSW: Powerful winds flip vehicles in Snowy Mountains</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Katherine Danks</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>SYDNEY, Aug 13</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Powerful alpine winds blew a semi-trailer onto its side and flipped several vehicles in the NSW Snowy Mountains today.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Emergency crews cleared five separate accidents caused by winds of up to 120kph, and late today were responding to at least one forest fire in the region.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A police spokesman said a semi-trailer on Kosciuszko Road near Jindabyne was blown onto its side about 11.30am (AEST).</p><p>"We've had very high wind gusts in the resorts today of well in excess of 120kph, which has caused a lot of chaos for traffic, particularly bigger vehicles like buses and trucks and vans," he said.</p><p>The semi-trailer driver escaped injury, but the road was closed for two hours while emergency crews righted the vehicle before it was towed for repairs.</p><p>A fire brigade spokesman said four separate accidents occurred on Alpine Way about midday.</p><p>The vehicles, including a 20-seater bus, were flipped onto their sides and roofs and one was blown off the road.</p><p>"They (the drivers and passengers) were very lucky to escape injury, any people involved in accidents are lucky to escape injury but these people were very lucky," the fire brigade spokesman said.</p><p>The road was reopened this afternoon after the vehicles were towed away.</p><p>The spokesperson described the wind as "absolutely horrendous", saying he was almost blown away as he helped mop up.</p><p>"We were delaying a number of tourist buses from leaving the resorts because of the high winds, we weren't prepared to take the risk of letting them drive," he said.</p><p>Winds also fanned a fire in state forests about 60km south of Cooma, a Forests NSW spokesman said.</p><p>The fire has swept across between 10 and 15 hectares of forest since it broke out shortly after midday.</p><p>The Snowy Mountains Highway between Bombala and Bemboka is closed.</p><p>The Bureau of Meteorology said the weather was not unusual for this time of year and the winds should calm down by late tonight.</p><p>"The front moved into Perth about two days ago and has now moved over here with some strong north-westerly winds ahead of it," he said.</p><p>"Around this time of year, you expect strong winds and for it to bring some rain with it."</p><p>The Roads and Traffic Authority said Kosciuszko Road was under traffic control and not suitable for trucks, buses and other high vehicles.</p><p>Tyre chains are required on parts of Kosciuszko Road and the Snowy Mountains Highway due to snow and ice, a spokesman said.</p><p>Police had received no reports of damage to houses or resorts.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4J6M-KD10-TX52-R2J5-00000-00Taipans, Bullets on song for finals2006-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 19Taipans, Bullets on song for finals

BRISBANE and Cairns signalled their playoffs intentions with impressive wins to close the regular season, while Sydney's vice-like grip on the National Basketball League was showing signs of coming loose.

Since the NBL changed to its current playoffs format two years ago, only one team outside the top four has managed to crack the semi-finals -- No. 5 Brisbane upsetting No. 4 Adelaide last season.

The top four are handsomely rewarded, with No. 1 and No. 2 given a bye into the semis and the third and fourth-ranked sides handed home-court advantage for their knockout quarter-finals.

But the Bullets and Taipans are keen to upset the form guide and both carry solid form into the

finals.

Brisbane showed their depth in a 120-77 mauling of an Adelaide side minus Brett Maher (calf), with seven players scoring in double figures led by Sam Mackinnon's 22.

That included a quiet nine-point, seven-board night from import Bobby Brannen and the absence of future Hall of Famers Derek Rucker and Lanard Copeland.

Depth, indeed.

The win locked up sixth and a home final against Perth on Wednesday.

The league has been waiting all season for the Bullets to show their potential and coach Joey Wright feels he may have found the formula.

''We definitely had to come out with that playoffs mentality,'' Wright said.

''I think the guys really did that. If you lose, you're gone and we love playing like that.''

Kings coach Brian Goorjian voiced his concerns after Cairns thrashed the three-time defending champions 107-84 on Saturday night.

Sydney played without Jason Smith and Ian Crosswhite and have a habit of switching off leading into the playoffs.

But the Kings have 10 days off before hosting game one of the semi-finals and Goorjian needs to lift a side that looks vulnerable without Crosswhite and Rolan Roberts.

''We look disorganised and we look like we have a real weakness inside,'' Goorjian said.

''We're going into the break with a forest fire around us. That's not the way you want to end a season.''

It's a different story for the Taipans, who have won three straight and host eighth-placed Hunter on Thursday.

Wollongong ensured a top-four spot for the fourth consecutive season with a 90-89 victory over a West Sydney side who will be grateful their season has ended.

NBL quarter-finals schedule:

Quarter-finals:

Wednesday: Brisbane Bullets (6th) v Perth Wildcats (7th) at Brisbane Convention Centre.

Thursday: Cairns Taipans (5th) v Hunter Pirates (8th) at Cairns Convention Centre.

Friday: Wollongong Hawks (3rd) v (winner of 6th v 7th) at Wollongong Entertainment Centre.

Saturday: Adelaide 36ers (4th) v (winner of 5th v 8th) at Distinctive Homes Dome, Adelaide.

urn:contentItem:49K2-M8C0-01S8-G1Y2-00000-00<published>1986-04-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>COMMOTIONS - ALL SET TO TAKE CITY BY STORM</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Commotions _ all set to take city by storm Brisbane will be the first stop in Australia for British band Lloyd Cole and the Commotions when they play Festival Hall on Thursday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Easy Pieces Tour will be their first tour of Australia since they formed early in 1984.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The five-piece group is centred on Lloyd Cole, the band's lead singer and songwriter.</p><p>He and the other Commotions, Blair Cowan (keyboards), Neil Clark (guitar), Lawrence Donegan (bass guitar) and Steven Irvine (drums) got together in Glasgow after playing in little-known bands.</p><p>They have made rapid inroads into the world music scene since the release of their first album, Rattlesnakes, in 1985.</p><p>It was well received by the critics and the singles from it, Rattlesnakes, Perfect Skin, Are You Ready To Be Heartbroken? and Forest Fire charted highly.</p><p>Their second album, Easy Pieces, released this year, has followed this success with three singles so far _ Brand New Friend, Lost Weekend, and Cut Me Down.</p><p>Lloyd Cole cites a variety of influences on his songwriting, including Bob Dylan (whom he regards as the consummate lyricist), blues and gospel music, Tom Waits, Paul Simon and Lou Reed _ and the writings of Tennessee Williams and Joan Didion.</p><p>Lloyd Cole and the Commotions will be supported by the five-piece Melbourne outfit Boom Crash Opera, who are supporting Icehouse on their south-east Queensland tour.</p><p>Their first single, Great Wall, has just made a favorable debut in the Australian charts.</p><p>LLOYD COLE</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC SHOWS LLOYD COLE</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:46PP-F560-015H-52WK-00000-00<published>2002-09-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Blaze battle a wake-up call, says fire chief</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>by Ken Sapwell</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIREMEN are hoping new containment lines will stop the spread of a fire which has destroyed more than 140 hectares of bushland in the foothills of Mount Warning since Thursday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Teams from five rural brigades began creating the firebreaks yesterday ahead of strong winds forecast for the area.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Tweed Shire rural fire service chief David Cook said up to seven houses were under threat, but firemen had so far managed to save them.</p><p>"The immediate threat to the homes has eased but we are putting in new containment lines in case the winds shift and become stronger," he said.</p><p>About 20 rural fire service volunteers and National Parks and Wildlife Service officers are keeping a close watch on the fire as it burns through rugged bushland near Eungella, west of Murwillumbah.</p><p>Superintendent Cook said the fire should serve as a wake-up call to people living in rural areas to ensure they have taken all measures to protect themselves and their property.</p><p>"This season is shaping up as one of the worst for a long time. Conditions are even worse than they were last year," he said. "The bush is very dry after the long drought and the fire danger is very high."</p><p>Supt Cook said the fire was the biggest since last season but local brigades had already been called out to several smaller fires in recent weeks.</p><p>He said brigades also faced potential problems in getting easy access to water because a lot of dams and creeks had dried up.</p><p>"The brigades all know where their closest available water sources are but they may take a little longer to reach because this year they are fewer and farther apart," he said.</p><p>Supt Cook said the cause of the fire was unknown at this stage but it would be investigated by brigade and National Park officers.</p><p>"No burn-off permits were issued for the area but we can't say that arson is suspected at this stage,' he said.</p><p>NSW Foresty Minister Kim Yeadon has warned that special forest fire investigators had been trained to catch arsonists this year.</p><p>"Arson is a senseless, dangerous and criminal act that endangers lives and property," said Mr Yeadon.</p><p>"With the help of the Rural Fire Service, State Forests now has trained fire investigators."</p><p>He said they would be initially based in the Hunter Valley and the NSW mid-north coast, with plans to train more officers to be based in other hotspots.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Pg. 34</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Nuclear secrets vanish - Laboratory under investigation</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>JOSEF HEBERT</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">TWO computer hard drives containing an array of nuclear secrets have disappeared from a highly secured vault at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, prompting a top-level investigation.</p><p nitf:lede="true">US Energy Department officials realised on June 1 that the sensitive material was missing.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> They believe the disappearance may be related to a forest fire that threatened the laboratory last month, forcing its evacuation.</p><p>"This is an extremely serious matter, and we're taking swift action to deal with it," laboratory director John Browne said yesterday.</p><p> For much of last year, the facility was embroiled in an espionage controversy involving a former scientist.</p><p> The hard drives, each slightly larger than a deck of cards, contained material used by the Nuclear Emergency Search Team, which is trained to respond to nuclear accidents or terrorism threats.</p><p> They contain detailed information on rendering nuclear weapons safe in an emergency.</p><p> "It's very sensitive technical data," Eugene Habiger, the Energy Department's senior security official, said.</p><p> Mr Habiger said he had not ruled out the possibility that the hard drives might have been misplaced or destroyed during the confusion caused by the threat from a bushfire that destroyed much of the community of Los Alamos.</p><p> Even if the hard drives are found, it is an embarrassment for the laboratory, where the nuclear bomb was created almost 60 years ago.</p><p> The laboratory was the centre of a security controversy in 1999 surrounding allegations against one of its former scientists, Wen Ho Lee.</p><p> Lee, arrested in December on charges of misusing secret nuclear data, is in jail awaiting trial.</p><p> Although he was under investigation for three years in connection with the alleged loss of US nuclear secrets to China, Lee has not been charged with espionage. He has denied giving secrets to anyone.</p><p> Senior Energy Department officials said yesterday there was no evidence that the loss of the hard drives involved espionage.</p><p> "The indicators just aren't there," Energy Department director of counter-intelligence Ed Curran said.</p><p> He noted that two identical drives, containing the same material, disappeared, whereas someone seeking the information for espionage would probably have taken only one.</p><p> Mr Curran said it was more likely the drives had been "misplaced, misused or accidentally destroyed".</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5D96-9G21-JD34-V2DF-00000-00Season of danger looming2014-10-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Season of danger looming

If last Sunday's almost 50 bushfire outbreaks were a sign of things to come, a community still reeling from the memory of the 2013 Dunalley fires could be forgiven for being more than worried. Police reporter PATRICK BILLINGS finds out exactly how the state is poised as the bushfire season looms.

TASMANIA'S looming bushfire season is an unknown beast.

Forecasters are warning of a more severe fire risk on the East Coast while climate scientists say we have less time to prepare for them.

Across the state indicators such as soil dryness are unseasonably high.

But the man heading up the fight against Tasmania's bushfires cautioned against alarm.

If Tasmania Fire Service's Chief Fire Officer MIke Brown has a take home message it's "Be Prepared".

"Just what we are going to get in the summer is still a little early to say but even even if we were to say 'average' we've still got to put it in the context that we live in a very fire prone region," Officer Brown said.

"Even in an average year we are going to get two, three, four days of bad conditions like severe or worse."

Officer Brown said the last few months had proven drier than usual despite forecasts predicting it would be wetter.

"(The forecast) is also showing a strong probability for the temperatures to be higher than average, in fact that's quite a strong probability greater than 80 per cent," he said.

These forecasts extend until December meaning the warmer conditions will spur fuel load growth right up to Tasmania's peak bushfire months - January and February.

September 28's "wild" outburst of 47 blazes, mainly in the south, was a clear reminder of just how quickly fire can menace Tasmanians.

The outlook

THE Bushfire and Natural Hazards CRC 's outlook for the 2014/15 has above normal potential bushfire risk for the East Coast between Swansea and St Helens and extending around Fingal.

The outlook has the south as relatively moist including the Derwent Valley and the Southern Midlands. Forest fires are expected to be relatively "normal" up to December in the eastern half of the state. The forest fire activity in the west will be suppressed. Similarly, moorland and scrub fuels are expected to be relatively normal while grassland fire activity will be low during spring and early summer.

Chief officer Mike Brown said outlooks were useful but nothing could be guaranteed.

"When we do suffer big losses it's more about what the weather is for four or five hours on a bad afternoon, not necessarily over three to six months of a fire bushfire season."

The climate

TASMANIA'S warming climate will lead to more high-fire danger weather, according to the Climate Change Institute's Professor Will Steffen.

In the long-term, the risk will increase with climate change pushing up the likelihood "of those really hot dry days on which bushfires break out."

"And they are occurring more frequently now," he said.

The Australian National University professor said there was evidence that fire behavior was also changing with bushfires occurring more frequently, burning larger areas and lasting longer.

"Those changes are in a direction that you would expect with a warming climate," he said.

This has seen emergency services change tack on bushfire mitigation.

This included the introduction of "catastrophic" as a new level of fire danger.

"One thing they've been saying is there is going to be some classes of fires that are so intense that we just have to get out of the way," Professor Steffen said.

Firefighters are also facing a shorter time period to reduce fuel loads because the bushfire season has become longer.

Profession Steffen said authorities had estimated they'd need to double funding of bushfire management by 2030.

Staying safe

EVEN when Tasmania's bushfire season is SNAFU - situation normal, all-fired up - it's critical communities and individuals take responsibility for managing the risk.

"The thing people really need to realise is when we've got those very bad fire days and conditions there's nothing we can do about controlling the bushfire as such," Chief Officer Mike Brown said.

"People under such conditions just can't expect they are necessarily going to have a fire truck to their doorstep when they dial triple zero.

"What we do has got to be more about recognising and protecting where the vulnerable people are at and protection of critical community assets."

As Tasmania's most destructive season approaches the fire service is rolling out two award winning bushfire mitigation programs around the state.

Community Protection Planning is a three-pronged attack that provides the community with information in the event of a bushfire, and ensures emergency managers and firefighters can respond effectively.

There are currently 150 community protection plans which are based on authorities going into communities and finding out what residents want protected.

"It protects the community, the people in the community and their assets from bushfire attack," Lyell Dean, community protection planning officer with the fire service, said.

The service's award-winning Bushfire-ready Neighbourhoods program includes fire preparedness activities including community forums, workshops, field days, bushfire rehearsals, women's programs, targeted resources and property

assessments

Behind the scenes

THE State Fire Management Council (SFMC) formulates bushfire fire management policy within Tasmania. This policy is used as the basis for all fire management planning. The council is overseen by an independent chairperson (currently vacant) and includes the Local Government Association of Tasmania, the Forest Industries Association, Tasmania Fire Service, ForestryTasmania, the Farmers and Graziers Association and the Parks and Wildlife Service.

A special unit within the council crunches data to model different fire scenarios to compare the effectiveness of various fuel reduction strategies.

This information flows to 10 Fire Management Area Committees.

In 2013 Tasmania was hit by several major bushfires across the state including one near Richmond.
