urn:contentItem:4GVP-S290-015G-Y316-00000-00<published>2005-08-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:51:51Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 21</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Malaysia prays for end to haze crisis</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Jahabar Sadiq and Ade Rina in Port Klang, Malaysia</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MALAYSIANS were desperately looking for a quick end to the country's worst pollution crisis in eight years yesterday as residents choked on acrid forest-fire smoke blowing in from Indonesia.</p><p nitf:lede="true">As the call to prayers echoed from mosques around this mainly Muslim country, Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi called for Muslims, Christians, Buddhists and Hindus to beg divine intervention to wash the skies of a week-long haze that has threatened public health.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"When something like this happens, we have to ask for God's help," Mr Abdullah was quoted as saying in Malay-language newspaper Utusan Malaysia.</p><p>There were early signs today of an easing in the haze, which has sent asthma attacks soaring, forced schools to close, grounded some flights and disrupted shipping.</p><p>But a weather forecaster cautioned that the haze might merely have shifted.</p><p>In Port Klang, Malaysia's biggest port and one of two areas declared an emergency zone on Thursday, the sun still appeared as a feeble orange disc through the smog but visibility had improved markedly, a slight breeze blew and fewer people wore face masks.</p><p>Northwest of Kuala Lumpur in Kuala Selangor, the second area put on an emergency footing yesterday, the smog still appeared thick but not as bad as Thursday, when air-pollution readings soared well into the hazardous zone. Sore throats and red eyes are commonplace and face masks are Kuala Lumpur's hottest seller.</p><p>The haze has also threatened the country's tourism industry at an important time when big-spending Middle East visitors flock to country.</p><p>In Sumatra, a short ferry ride away from peninsular Malaysia, fires still raged, some of them deep in thick forests which would take more than a day to reach without the aid of helicopters, said a local police chief at Rokan Hilir, where fires have been burning through swampy, remote country.</p><p>"The equipment we use is conventional. We spray water on the fire. Today the condition is better than the past few days," Rokan Hilir Police Chief Zulkifli said by telephone.</p><p>"As for the fire far inside the forest, we will need one to one-and-a-half days to get there. We don't have helicopters."</p><p>Malaysia plans to send 100 firefighters to Sumatra to help Indonesia douse the flames.</p><p>Air-pollution readings in Malaysia have yet to match the dangerous levels of 1997 when mainly Indonesian fires blotted out skies across South-East Asia, badly hurting tourism.</p><p>Singapore and even many parts of peninsular Malaysia, including many beach resorts, have been spared this time.</p><p>The haze has forced hundreds of schools to close in and around Kuala Lumpur and also hit some key industrial sites, forcing Port Klang and an airport close to the capital to close for several hours.</p><p> -- Reuters</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:54MN-MMV1-F0N8-R07K-00000-00`Reservation' is not the same as `conservation'2012-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisPg. 13`Reservation' is not the same as `conservation'Felicity Kirkpatric

THERE are two recent statements made by green politicians that are worthy of support. Firstly, that ``all forests have high conservation value" and secondly that forest policy should be ``implemented using sound conservation principles". Neither of these have been applied to the current debacle, which has forged nouveau forest policy. A little basic biological and ecological knowledge applied to decision-making processes during the past 30 years, would have avoided any crisis. Decisions appear to have been made in a knowledge vacuum by myopic, politically driven groups of individuals with little regard for and understanding of the social, economic or environmental impacts on the people of Tasmania and on the forests.

Forest reservation does not equate to forest conservation. Focus needs to be shifted away from putting ``high conservation value" labels on forests with a view to locking them up in an even larger area of poorly managed reserves. Seeking answers to questions, such as, ``what are our conservation goals?" and ``how should we manage forests to achieve conservation goals?" are much more worthy pursuits. Applying some simple biology to forest management, it is obvious that our fire-sensitive rainforest communities require long periods free from disturbance. The scientific understanding of these forests has led to the exclusion of rainforest from forest harvesting in Tasmania. The majestic, tall, wet eucalypt forests, comprising much of the area to be tagged high conservation value, are very different. It is accepted that eucalypt forests are fire dependent. In wet eucalypt forests it is common for 90 to 100 per cent of the eucalypts to be of the same age, arising from a single stand- destroying fire. Yes, in tall, wet eucalypt forests the current generation must die before the next can arise. Eucalypt seed will only germinate on bare mineral soil, created naturally by intense forest fire. Therefore, the conservation of wet eucalypt forests becomes more complex than simply applying a high conservation value label then locking it up in a reserve. If there is no fire in a eucalypt forest within a 350 to 500 year period, the lifespan of a eucalypt, then the genes of these individuals will be lost forever. Scientists suggest fires in the one-in-100 to -300-year frequency range should maintain eucalypt domination with the maximum diversity in understorey species. Another goal of forest conservation must be to maintain a range of forest age classes at the landscape level, both regrowth and ecologically mature. A focus only on ``old- growth" forest is quite foolhardy. A plan for the distribution of forest communities across dimensions of time and space is essential. While reserving large areas of wilderness, where the wild takes care of itself, is globally accepted, some consideration is required to the make-up of that wilderness and the forces that shape it, particularly for fire-dependent communities. Some 47 per cent of our state is in a reserve of some kind. These reserves have had little planned ecological burning and are largely at the mercy of bushfire as the tool of regeneration. Bushfires in 1897-98 burnt out about a third of the state, including about half of the area that is now Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area. Fires in 1933-34 burnt out about a third of that heritage area, and since 1930 some 850,000 hectares of the area has been burnt. Hence, a substantial proportion of the area that we have deemed to have World Heritage value and high conservation value is the result of being burnt out in the past 80 to 110 years; it barely qualifies as being ``old growth". The majority of the above fires were lit by early European explorers attempting to ``open up the country". Areas of forest, outside any reserve system, need to be actively managed, if only for risk management and controlling fire frequencies. Fire management needs to be part of forest conservation. We should not be ``putting all our eggs in the one (forest reservation) basket", where management is left to chance. Current forest policy, and popular belief, is underpinned by the mistruth that disturbances such as fire and timber harvesting destroy forests and therefore reservation and the prevention of disturbance must conserve them. Policy based on this presumption is fundamentally flawed and may lead to reductions in biodiversity values, and forest conservation being at the mercy of irregular intense uncontrolled bushfires, or an absence of fire.

urn:contentItem:4P6W-1D30-TXN5-R2JW-00000-00LETTERS2004-02-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:51:51ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESLettersPg. 14LETTERS

Shark story does

have funny aspect

The chronicle of the shark which, with bulldog-like tenacity, would not let go, certainly had, in the victim's words, "a side of humour to it" ("Shark sinks its teeth in for the long haul", Herald, February 12).

Perhaps the strangest feature of the story, however, is the apparent lack of licensed drivers among those who helped, so that Mr Tresoglavic drove himself, plus attached shark, to the clubhouse and then, accompanied by the finally detached shark, to

the hospital.

Ken Knight,

Hornsby, February 12.

My father served with Australians in the Philippines during World War II, and he always told me Aussies were tough, but until I read about Luke Tresoglavic out for a stroll with a shark attached to his leg, I simply had no idea.

Jim Thayer,

Seattle (US), February 12.

Bit of the raw prawn

Every night we see on our TV news scenes of horror and disaster with bombings and earthquakes, and yet the ABC has to broadcast a warning before the cooking show Surfing the Menu because a yabbie will be decapitated while still alive.

J. Archer,

Waitara, February 12.

Thin man returns

It took a long time, Shane, but your mum's diuretic has worked beautifully.

Joan Brown,

Orange, February 12.

Warne? Yawn.

Glen Sorensen,

Bondi Junction, February 12.

Better than no attention

Thank you, Judith Ireland (Heckler, February 12), for criticising the baby boomers, for celebrities thrive on criticism, like a forest fire fanned by a strong wind.

Mustafa Erem,

Terrigal, February 12.

To be fair, Rene could pay

Surely some arrangement could be worked out whereby Rene Rivkin pays to have his prison sentence reduced significantly. Rich people can pay to have their entry score to university reduced below that which poor people must attain.

Some would see both these practices as grossly immoral, but I can't see anything wrong with them. After all, they are just the extension of market principles into exciting new realms.

Ted Trainer,

Holsworthy, February 12.

Still stewing on it

Did the vegan hardliners issue a fatwah on Dr Atkins ("Vegans weigh in, calling diet guru Atkins a big fat liar", Herald, February 12)? He's been dead a year and they are still fighting for the cause. Looks to me like a clash of belief systems within the US medical establishment.

Anthony Cameron,

Manly, February 12.

Holes in safety net

Why does Medicare need a safety net? I was led to believe that Medicare was the safety net. Has the Government cut so many holes in it?

Mitch McTavish,

Cootamundra, February 11.
